name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Sirpa Pietikäinen, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on care services in the EU for better gender equality (2018/2077(INI) (A8-0352/2018).

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: as a replacement for the rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased to start today's debate on sirpa Petikainen's report on care services in the European Union in the context of equality between women and men. Unfortunately, it is very telling that Sirpa cannot present this report in person today precisely because of her caring responsibilities. Sirpa, we keep our fingers crossed that everything is fine! To begin with, I would like to point out that the report is temporarily and thematically linked to the legislative work-life balance package, which contains proposals from the European Commission on a minimum standard for parental leave, as well as paternity leave and carers' leave. Sirpa Petikainen's report complements this legislative package, showing the current situation and challenges in care services, both for children and for vulnerable adults. Why are we considering care services today in the context of women's rights? Because this very difficult, demanding work is done primarily by women. If they take care of a family member, sometimes they have to give up their normal activities, sometimes they work for years without a single day of leave. Their work is free of charge, and if they do it for another family, even if it is paid, it is very often undeclared work. 80% of care services and services in the domestic worker sector in general are black work without social security, without a future, without a pension. This report deals with what is most important in every person's life – human dignity. We are talking here, in this report, about women, also because caring for dependent persons is the first obstacle to women's participation in the labour market. Career breaks, subsequent career starts, procrastination of promotion, because children, early exit from the labour market, because parents require care, choosing educational and professional paths that allow them to be available to the family and not to the employer result in lower wages, slower increases, periods of inactivity and, as a result, a low pension. I would remind you that the pension gap in the European Union is currently 38%. As caring responsibilities are the first obstacle to professional achievement for women, ensuring accessible and quality care services for children and adults is the first duty of politicians and policy makers in this regard. Demographics are unrelenting – care needs are on the rise, the problem is getting more serious and will grow, and women are the victims of a lack of effective solutions. Regulating this market, formalising care work and finding solutions for the health and financial security of informal carers are the main thesis of the Report by Sirpa Petikainen, to whom the political groups have tabled many amendments and thank you very much for all these amendments on behalf of the rapporteur. The rapporteur raises many important and urgent care needs in the report. draws attention to the fact that caring objectives are most effectively pursued in the family and environmental rather than institutional systems; It further stresses the importance of such home-based care, based on relationships with family and friends, and calls for infrastructure and organisational solutions that strengthen home, family and environmental care. It is essential that every type of care is supported regardless of the professional status of the caregiver, that is to say, that it is accessible to both full-time and part-time workers and the unemployed, and that the burden of care policies, the main direction of their development, should be based on home care, chamber care and not on institutions. On behalf of the PPE Group, I support this report, while pointing out that, with regard to some of the amendments tabled by our colleagues in other political groups concerning the separate taxation of women and men, the inclusion of monitoring of care systems in the European Semester or the translation of the burden of care into institutions, our political group will vote against, as these are proposals that interfere with subsidiarity and family policy.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Parliament and the rapporteur, Sirpa Pietikäinen, for the work done on this dossier, which highlights some key elements and issues to tackle with regard to care services. The Commission shares the Parliament’s position that such services are crucial for gender equality, in particular to allow women’s equal participation in the labour market and for women’s empowerment and the work-life balance of working parents and carers.  This was also part of the work-life balance legislative proposal and the Action Plan to tackle the gender pay gap of November 2017. Ensuring that women and men can combine work with care duties is a key element to close the gender employment gap. Two sides of the same coin are important: having working arrangements that allow workers to combine it with care responsibilities and having access to affordable and high—quality care services for children and other dependents.  This will help tackle the gender pay gap, as was highlighted at the Equal Pay Day just a few weeks ago. Having access to care services and working arrangements adapted to one’s care needs are determinant for women to achieve their full employment potential. In addition, the value of women’s work and equal pay for work of equal value are crucial. Indeed, women often carry out care work. It is therefore important to reflect upon the effectiveness of the implementation of the current equal pay provisions, for which I intend to launch an open consultation over the next couple of weeks. The work-life balance proposal is also important in this context. It will offer choices for working parents and is closely linked to affordable childcare facilities. We are making good progress in the trilogues and I hope that we will be able to finalise them before the end of the year. With regard to childcare, the Commission adopted a report on the Barcelona objectives on 8 May this year. While the overall targets for childcare have been reached on average for the EU, less than half of the Member States have met these targets. In order to meet the targets, childcare should not only be available, but also be affordable and of high quality. This is essential for the social inclusion of children from a disadvantaged background, in order for them to have a good educational start in life.  The Commission has also adopted a proposal for a Council recommendation on affordable and high-quality early childhood education and care systems, including a quality framework based on principles of availability, affordability, inclusion, a good educational programme, professionalisation and good working conditions for educational staff, good governance and monitoring.  Overall, I would like to recall that these issues are monitored in the European Semester process and are reflected in many national reports. Funding through the European Structural and Investment Funds should be prioritised, particularly for those countries lagging behind. I look forward to this debate today.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the area of care services is undoubtedly important and, given demographic developments, it will further strengthen its importance in the future. This sector is primarily the responsibility of the Member States, it is the Member States that have an interest in improving the conditions for all workers in these services, whether they are women or men. It is the Member States that must emphasise the quality and accessibility of all care services. I, of course, see the link between this report and the Directive on the re-organisation of private and working life. In this area, I also support the inclusion of care time in leave so that carers have the best possible conditions for their work. However, the competences of the Member States must be respected in this matter. The gender perspective applies only to care services to a limited way. The report in this regard, I dare say, is not balanced and omers a number of factors that should be taken into account, because care services are indeed comprehensive, they affect other aspects such as age, such as vulnerable groups and other factors. I consider it problematic, inter alia, that there is a call for separate taxation of spouses, for the broadest possible concept of family, for the Commission to regulate and control the quality of services, to establish a binding framework for minimum standards for working conditions in the sector and to guarantee financial support for carers. In my opinion, these and other points significantly interfere with the competence of the Member States. I dare say that not only in my opinion, but also according to part of the Group of the European People's Party. Nevertheless, thank you for drawing up this report as a certain motivation for our further work.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, around eighty million dependents live in the European Union. 80% of the care services provided in the European Union are for informal unpaid caregivers, and 75% of them are women. This has a lot to do with the problem that currently exists in the pay gap and pension gap. It is scandalous that in 21st-century Europe women are receiving an average of 45% less in pensions than men. And another revealing fact also drawn from the report is how austerity policies have contributed to the deterioration of public services, so fundamental to achieving this principle of conciliation and co-responsibility. We therefore welcome the report and emphasize compliance with those requests to advance the reconciliation of family and work life and co-responsibility. That is why we are also calling here today for an agreement on the part of the Council and for negotiations with this Parliament with the Parental Leave Directive. It's critical. It's indispensable. Women have been reconciling all our lives. Now we also need it to be our companions, that it is men who are incorporated into this task. In addition, this report also refers to the need for social rights and pension recognition systems to be taken into account with caregivers. And so I emphasize here initiatives such as that of the Government of Spain, with its draft budgets, which includes re-incorporating women who care for dependents into social security systems. Only with these initiatives will we be able to move forward with real co-responsibility for the care of dependents and children in the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Dear Chairman, gender equality is something we absolutely must strive for, but it must be equality on occasions, not in end-to-end outcomes. Women need to have the same opportunity as men to come true in various fields of life, and whether they do, that's their personal business. I can't help feeling that feminists have a pre-planned life for all women, and those who want to live differently for them are slave girls or just go crazy. So much for the diversity they talk about a lot. Measuring inequalities at the level of endpoints is completely wrong because it does not take into account the different biologically defined affinity and roles. The mother is the mother, and the father is the father – and they have different roles in the child's life according to which some other life choices are made. It's perfectly natural.  Our task is to provide both women and men with the opportunity to choose, not to impose on them their vision of their relationships with each other.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, how Europe manages care services, how we treat its professionals will say a lot about what we want from the European Union and its future.  The care of dependents, adults and children has traditionally been a role of women for which they have not been remunerated or recognized. Even today, 80% of the care services provided in the Union are for unpaid caregivers, 75% to 80% of whom are women.  The trend in Europe is negative: over the past ten years, women's time in care, domestic work and social activities has increased compared to men. This has serious economic and social consequences, it is an obstacle to achieving the Union's objectives on gender equality.  It's time to change this. It is time for us to take care of others as a key social task that marks the level of well-being and even the moral level of a society.  It is time for care services to be recognised and regulated as what they are: a European pillar of social rights.  Both the European institutions and the Member States must make an effort in this area: we must define them correctly, so that they include child care and early childhood education, assistance to the elderly and also assistance to people with disabilities. We must make them accessible and flexible to meet the needs of families with different needs and personal situations.  Let us think of single-parent families, self-employed families, shift workers in a deeply and radically transformed world of work. Let us think of a society that must evolve in order to adapt to these new challenges, because in a Europe it cares for, in a Europe that protects, in a Europe that leaves no one behind, caring must be a respected, safe, transparent, professional and adequately remunerated activity.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, in recent years the lack of sufficiently developed public care and assistance services and support for caregivers has led many women to have been forced to return to care. Austerity and cuts in public services have done extraordinary damage to equality between men and women. And then, of course, this has an impact on the pay gap and the pension gap, because many women are forced to leave their jobs to devote themselves to care. It is therefore very important to develop this essential pillar of the welfare state. I welcome the fact that today we approve this report which clearly calls for the development of public services, clear investments in Member States' care and care services and support for professionals, caregivers and training; and that this is a developed pillar that allows, once and for all, to have an egalitarian society. There will be no egalitarian society in the European Union if we do not have public services that are able to cover this essential pillar of the welfare state.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, two years after the adoption of my report on domestic and care staff, we are still waiting for a legislative initiative in the field of care. That is why we are asking for it again through the text of this report. We have worked with my colleague Sirpa Pietikäinen to take another step towards recognising and regulating the care sector. I hope that this time colleagues will not turn their backs on the millions of workers in the sector who look after our loved ones and, unfortunately, often stay in the dark while we come to light in search of our personal and professional development. So what do we need to bring this invisible category of workers to light? Firstly, regulation and recognition of the profession at European level. Secondly, brave European investments in care structures at community level. Thirdly, strengthening the cut-out social state. Fourthly, programmes to train, support and enhance the skills of care staff. Colleagues, the field of care and its management may seem like a mountain to you. But we have to go up and not just look at it. It's not going to get any smaller. It's time to take care of the care staff. That is why I call on you to vote in favour of our report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, helping so-called 'rural' families by rehabilitating local care centres or setting up early childhood centres, recognising the work of those you call 'helpers', avoiding discrimination in employment when a mother or father has made the choice to serve her family are good proposals. But, as is often the case, your good intentions are being erased under the European ideology, and it is to the European Commission - through solidarity funds that are not its own - that you entrust this task. You are asking the States to better distribute European funds, but you simply forget that this is one of the sovereigntys that you have taken away from the Member States, since it is a power that has been given to the regions. Finally, you specify the real objective of the report, which is absolutely not the well-being of families, but the 370 billion that would be the shortfall for the European Union and big business in one year when women choose to serve their families rather than work. You admit it: a mother must return to work as soon as possible at the end of her maternity leave. And to facilitate this return, you ask men to take responsibility. The motivation of this type of text once again demonstrates your ambitions. I therefore reaffirm that family policies are and must remain a prerogative of sovereign states. The European Union does not have to enter into the privacy of families.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the strategy of the European Union and industrialists to balance women's work and personal lives is aimed at increasing their flexibility and exploitation. Behind inexpensive wishes in the report, the care of the family and the elderly, instead of social right and responsibility, turns into an individual affair that at most is shared between women and men. It is even proposed that women should be withdrawn from work in order to care for family members in return for a subsidy. The dismantling and commercialisation of family and state nursery support infrastructures and services, the European Union and the SYRIZA-ANEL government call them an "elementary network of public and private structures" with the working-class family burdened with unbearable burdens for the self-evident. And women's participation in social work - and indeed in galleon terms - conflicts with motherhood. After all - and under the seal of the Court of Justice of the European Union - the dismissal of pregnant women has recently been legitimised. Women of the working-class strata, with their class struggle and social liberation from the shackles of the exploitative system, must act on their parity and emancipation. Can!

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – In my opinion, when we talk about the importance of care services in the European Union, today and in the future, we need to talk fundamentally about two aspects: how care services promote and contribute to equality between women and men at work and at home, and how we can ensure that the wages, social protection, safety and health of carers at work are improved. Unfortunately, the facts show that the absence of adequate, accessible and safe care services has a dire impact on women's occupational self-realisation, and, in a more earthly way, simply creates the conditions for women's poverty, which accumulates up to just under 40% of the pension gap in old age. Why is that? And because the emancipation of women at home is much slower than in the professional sphere. After all, most often, if a woman chooses a career, it is understood as an additional choice of her next to the unpaid care of children or sick family members, or household chores. Women are still punished if they choose to have both a career and a family. However, it is not only women who suffer as a result. This affects society. Yes, the first, most important step towards equality has been taken not only at work, but also at home, which I once again want to thank the European Commission, and thank you, Commissioner. I am referring to the proposal for a Work-Private Life Balance Directive. I would also like to call on the Council not to make a mistake and not to detract from this long-awaited legislation to one that does not bring tangible benefits. I want to call on national governments to understand that this legislation is the best investment for the future of our people, in our countries and in our Union. And invite us to see this as a manifestation of solidarity.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his We need "care without subordination". These famous words come from Gertrud Åström, who laid the foundation for the strategic gender equality work in my country, Sweden. The care sector is female-dominated and underpaid. Some of the most important jobs in our society – caring for children and young people, sick and old – are so heavy and poorly funded that almost no one can work full-time. No machine or smart robot can offer what a human can – a warm hand, comfort, kind words in moments when life is at its most challenging. It terrifies me and curses that our nurses and doctors barely have time to have lunch or go to the toilet, that preschools cannot find trained pre-school teachers, that our old ones are denied a moment's fresh air, and that women have to be afraid to have children because midwives are on strike. It can't go on like this! In my society, we prioritize the work of women. We give it higher status and properly paid.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, 75% of those engaged in care work in the European Union are women.  Care work, historically carried out by women invisibly in the private sphere, is now a source of precariousness in the labour market and yet essential for the sustainability of life. Care cannot continue to be done informally at the expense of women's living conditions and health. I therefore appeal to common sense to remove the reference to informal care.  We must professionalize the sector and guarantee labour rights for three reasons: the first, because it is a right, for social justice; secondly, because it is a necessity of our societies; and thirdly, because it is not only a problem to be solved, but it is also an opportunity.  According to the International Conference of Trade Unions, in OECD countries, investing between 2% and 6%, many of them could increase employment by up to 8%.  Investing in quality care with quality utilities can be a great opportunity to generate quality jobs and improve the lives of our societies.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The explanatory memorandum to this report regrets that there is a negative trend that women spend more time in domestic care and do unpaid work. Such things can only be written by a person who completely does not understand what he writes about and completely does not understand economics. If we have two people: one lady works at the post office and the other works from home, taking care of her children free of charge, then according to the rapporteurs this situation is worse than when they swap places: the mother will go to work for the post office, and the post office will come to take care of her children. Both will then have paid work. In your opinion, this situation is better, as I understand it. Why do you think it's better? Because then the state will "put a paw" on the money from their salaries. That's what you mean. It hurts you that when you do your job free of charge at home, you don't have tax money from it. And you want to collect where you have not sowed. You want to choose someone else's money and you want as much money as possible to go into your budgets. It's not about people's welfare, it's about your full pockets.

name: Anna HEDH
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr This is a very important feminist issue, as it affects women's daily lives and society at large. However, I think that the report goes far too far. How Member States organise their care shall be up to the Member States and no others. However, the gender perspective is extremely important and cannot be emphasised enough. Women and men in the EU participate in the labour market to varying degrees. Women take primary responsibility for caring for children and unpaid domestic work. Some leave the labour market for some time. Some people never come back. The situation is devastating economically. For women, income is reduced – not to mention retirement. In addition, society loses lots of money because women do not work to the same extent as men. Women are also discriminated against in care. Women have less access to care, have longer waiting times, and their concerns are not taken as seriously as men's. We must talk about all this! All this must be with us in our political work! All of us in this house have just as much responsibility, whether we are women or men!

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, and thanks to our rapporteur. I’m very conscious, colleagues, that there are carers who have not slept overnight because they’re looking after a sick child, a person with a disability or elderly parents, and the statistics that 80% of care is unpaid and informal and that 75% of it is done by women are worth repeating. This isn’t just an ideological debate or about money; this is about the type of society we want for the future. We are going to face an enormous challenge in encouraging people to get into the paid care sector because it is low-paid, and indeed we have smaller families, so we will have fewer people who are available to care. And maybe for selfish reasons those of us of a certain age in this House might ponder those difficulties. So I think this debate should be about a vision for the future, where people who care are cared for by others and have respite and recognition.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, 32 million children of pre-school age: the analysis shows that the situation of childcare – and not only of children, but also of the elderly – in the European Union does not look good. It is a failure, of course, of the Member States, but also of the European Union, because we have a lot of directives, a lot of regulations which, in fact, do not achieve their purpose. We need infrastructure. We need to allocate funds in the countryside, where most children are and where we do not have the opportunity to provide them with effective and fair care. We need to ensure good and fair and fair pay for women, because, for the most part, women do this care and, yes, we need to think about how we can institutionally improve the situation, because, lo and behold, we have situations – in Finland, for example – when children are taken and separated from their mothers and forcibly detained in the institution. So we have a lot of things to do and, for a fair thing, we also need to improve women's pay and legislation on the rights of the child and the care of the elderly.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the unequal participation of men and women in the care of children, the elderly or people with chronic diseases, in carrying out household tasks and in participating in social activities in the European Union remains an alarming factor in our society. Of the care provided in the European Union, 80% are provided by unpaid informers, of whom 75% are women, so there is an urgent need to move forward at European level with legal instruments capable of promoting gender equality in the provision of care and in the homogeneous regulation of the profession. I would like to point out that some Member States have already set up programmes to support and protect Alzheimer's patients, their families and health professionals. So I ask: for when the creation of a similar program for formal and formal carers? Ladies and gentlemen, given that the vast majority of carers are women, the future directive on work-life balance must effectively protect women and ensure that women are not dismissed for reasons intrinsic to the female condition.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, we are discussing a serious issue, which is directly related to the care of both the elderly and children. An issue that concerns modern society. Of course, in essence, it is a social right of citizens and the corresponding obligation of the state is to ensure this care for both the elderly and children. The figures show that 80% of care is provided by unpaid informal carers, 75% of whom are women. At the same time, 27.5% of this proportion of women work part-time in order to be able to look after children. There must therefore be a proper combination of work and care services. Of course, austerity has the effect of reducing public spending and hitting this social right. In Greece, more than 35 000 children have been left out of kindergarten this year. It is understood that concrete measures must be taken and tax incentives given and, of course, the farmer must be strengthened, so that she too can have plenty of time, given that childcare is of great concern to her.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The conditions for the care of both children and dependent persons vary considerably from one European Union country to one other. This applies both to access to infrastructure and to the quality of the services provided. I therefore believe that, although we need a common strategy and an integrated approach at EU level, the 'one solution for all' approach should not be applied, but individual local and regional needs should be taken into account.  In order to improve standards of care services, it is worth using the tools that cohesion policy offers us. I believe that the Structural Funds should be aimed at investing in infrastructure in those areas where such centres are still lacking or need to be modernised. The European Cohesion Fund, on the other hand, can both support staff and help young parents and carers to return to the labour market after a break due to care.  It is also important to promote a flexible approach among employers so that carers can combine their responsibilities with their careers.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it’s very important that this report underlines the role of women at the care services within the context of the work-life balance proposal and emphasises the importance of the availability of diverse, quality, accessible and affordable care infrastructure and support for childcare and care for other dependents – either at home or in home-like situations. This is very important to have it in a report of the European Parliament. I would like to underline the fact that the draft report discusses as well the targets for development of different services, and finally includes recommendations related to the funding of care infrastructure and services. The compromises found for the focus on the informal care sector an improvement of conditions in the formal care sector. In addition, my Group, the S&D, underlined the need for investment by the public sector in care services as well as in awareness of the difficult situation of women working in this sector, having in mind the different familiar composition which leads to needing care. The S&D Group also demands to set social progress indicators to be monitored in the context of the European semesters, in addition to be able to reach the Barcelona targets.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, in today’s societies, care work is disproportionately carried out by women and girls. They do most of this work for free, and it’s taken for granted. Women’s care work, both formal and informal, is sadly still a source of shocking inequality. Austerity policies and the resulting increase in poverty have seriously exacerbated the problem as vital services have been cut to the bone. Yet, changing demographics mean that more of us are in need of care, so we’re seeing families and dependants forced to fall back on traditional gender roles. Domestic workers, who are mostly migrant women, are open to terrible abuse by employers. Meanwhile, in the UK, Brexit threatens the future supply of care workers, leaving the elderly and disabled vulnerable. I’m happy to see that the report stresses that EU funding should support the transition from institutionalisation to a community and family—based model of care services, both for disabled people and other vulnerable groups such as children, and also that the report highlights the need for a work—life balance.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, many children in Central and Eastern European countries are at risk of not being effectively supported in their early ages in order to reach their full potential. If we want the future generation of the European Union to form a healthier and more successful society we need to make early childhood development a priority.  There is growing evidence that preventive education can generate lifelong changes in cognitive development and social behaviour when children reach adolescence and adulthood. Early childhood intervention programmes can alleviate the issues of social exclusion, unemployment, poverty, and would also reduce the proportion of mental disease in Member States. In Romania, 40% of disabled children don’t attend any form of education, for instance.  Helping vulnerable children to develop at an early age, according to their needs, is part of a sustainable solution to social integration in the EU. I call on the EU to share best practices and I urge the Commission to present a European carers programme that includes early childhood intervention services.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, an ageing Europe is in dire need of well-functioning rules of the game. Fewer children are being born, the dependency ratio is getting quite poor. In many European Member States, there are more and more older people and more people are needed for care services, both in informal care and in public services. It requires us to take action and to do so so that the most vulnerable Europeans are taken care of and cared for. I do not believe that equality, justice and equality are away from anyone in this world. They are values that we all have to work for.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Sirpa for his excellent work on this important report on leave. In the European Union, the unequal participation of men and women in care activities and domestic tasks remains an ongoing challenge. The fact that women spend a disproportionate amount of time on unpaid work compared to men has serious economic and social consequences and is an obstacle to achieving the Eu ropean Union's objectives on gender equality.  The latest available data tell us of an average gender pension gap in the European Union of 40 % as a result of inequalities accumulated over women's lifetime compared to men in the labour market. One of the main reasons why women are inactive in the labour market is the limited possibilities of efficiently, flexibly and cost-effectively combining paid employment and family responsibilities.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for your interventions which are very valuable to the Commission. Let me react on several comments here regarding the competence of the European Union to legislate and to come with measures in this area.  The Commission analysed very thoroughly the legal competences of the EU in this field of a combination of work and family duties, and as you mentioned here the family matters fall under the competence of the Member States, while gender equality is the competence of the EU, and also we have a very strong economical case because we see in all the Member States, without any exception, that the situation is not sustainable, that we cannot continue like that, that we have to enable women who want to work to work and to share also the family duties. I speak about the unsustainability of the current situation and economically inadvisable solution because we have at this moment more than 60% of the graduates at universities who are women, and then we do not use the potential of women at all or only in a limited way. Many of you mentioned here the worrying demographic line. This is something we have to do a lot about and while speaking about the social services we have a tendency to speak about the problem of women. No, this is the problem of the whole society. If we do not solve this problem, we will have in the near future a very strong issue. The Commission’s position on how to solve the problem was to respect the limited competences we have, but to use them in full, and this is reflected in our work-life balance package which, as you know, is the combination of legislative and non-legislative measures. As for the legislation, you know very well what we are proposing. As for non-legislative measures, we are recommending that the Member States take steps to have a fairer social and tax system which does not bring disadvantages to women who are usually considered to be the first parents, and also we are addressing the Member States through country-specific recommendations, where we are proposing to increase the salaries in the jobs in the social services sphere and in the jobs which are predominantly occupied by women, it means the education, social services and health sector. Among the non-legislative proposals, there is also a very strong recommendation to use more public funding for better social services which will be more achievable or accessible and more affordable for all the people who need such services, and I heard from this side of the Parliament that this is the money of the Member States, so they should have a sovereign the competence to decide. Well, we recommend something regarding the EU money, the EU structural funds, where for many years the position of the Commission was that the social services fall under the national competence and it is the traditional, the classical cost, so it should be covered by the Member States. This Commission came with a change of paradigm, we said no, this is not the cost, this is investment and this is investment which has a very quick and high return of investment which pays off and which can be covered by EU money, and this is a change, and some Member States reacted positively on that and some are still maybe hesitating. We want to do everything to through the work-life balance package. The trialogs are on a good track and I do hope that it will be one of our legacies that we came with the legislation which can bring a real difference for the lives of people. Last comment on work-life balance legislation. No, we are not dictating how the people should live. We are not dictating how the people in the family, the men/women, should divide their duties. We are just doing what I am sure is our obligation, opening wider variety of choices for working parents and for carers to combine better their duties in the family and at the workplace. So, ladies and gentlemen, thank you once again for this debate. Thank you once again for the important report which is coherent with what the Commission wants and plans and tries to promote. We indeed need to have a comprehensive approach and to make sure that this issue needs to remain high on the European agenda with a view to reach gender equality.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I sincerely thank you for all the comments and comments made during this debate to the very important report by Sirpa Pietikäinen. I thank Commissioner Jourova for her declaration of support for care policy at European Union level and for the work-life balance package, which is now being discussed in the trilogue, and I keep my fingers crossed that these talks will be successful.  The issue of caring for dependent persons – both children, adults and people with disabilities – requires urgent action in the Member States. From the European Parliament, we call on all those who take decisions on this matter to take urgent action. The problem of care is a problem for women, because the carers are primarily women. Most of them, as we said here today, work free of charge or illegally without social security, without a pension in the future, without leave, straining their health and strength. This is unfair and needs to be changed also because caring responsibilities are the first obstacle for women to pursue work, and breaks and restrictions at work result in a pension gap of 40% in the world's richest economy. We need good quality care services, most of which are provided in the family and environmental system. We need a salary for the work of a caregiver and to take that work into account when calculating the pension. We need support for informal carers regardless of their professional status so that they do not have to give up their jobs in order to be cared for by their loved ones. We need urgent solutions at Member State level, as well as a European strategy and plan, so that national policies can be implemented more effectively. Ensuring accessible and quality care services for children and adults is the first duty of politicians and decision-makers, that is, us too. Why? Because demographics are inexorable. Care needs are growing. The problem is becoming more serious and will grow, and women are the victims of a lack of effective solutions in this area.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 15 November 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Written. – Mr President, it is very important that high-quality care services for children, the elderly and the disabled are available throughout the Union. The responsibility for caring for loved ones is still more often the responsibility of women than men. Reliable and accessible services therefore also enable women to participate in working life. Care services affect our fellow human beings, so it is clear that they must be of high quality and such that ordinary people can afford them.  We still have to talk about reconciling work and family life. Although attitudes have changed, there is still work to be done to ensure a balanced distribution of responsibility for caring for home and family. I hope that progress will already be made on these issues, where quality care services play a key role.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Written. Mr President, although I hoped that it would no longer be necessary in the meantime, I would like to point it out again: we must close the wage gap. On average, women earn 16% less than men. Although progress has been made before, recent research shows that the gap has not been shrinking for two years. Meanwhile, women are at increased risk of poverty, especially single-parent families and pensioners. Unacceptable and inexplicable if you ask me. Mr President, gender equality in the workplace has not yet been achieved. Leave at the birth of a child should not be a limitation to a career, but a right for all. Unpaid work as a household or care should not force people to work part-time. Let us give everyone the opportunity to make a work-life balance themselves, without gender having an impact on it. Mr President, equality does not come naturally, it is time for action and there is much to do. Extending paternity leave is an example of this. The provision of good and affordable care services is also important. These include childcare, elderly care and facilities for the disabled or chronically ill. The solutions are ready: let's close the gap once and for all.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – When it comes to creating a balance between family and work life, it is extremely important that women, because mostly they are the ones who "bear the burden" of care on their backs, but equally men, have at their disposal quality and affordable public and private care services to entrust their children or sick or elderly family members.  It is therefore important to invest in creating adequate infrastructure, it is important to invest in care education. On the other hand, it is necessary to recognise the value of the carer's work and evaluate it as such and to provide carers with all the rights derived from their employment relationship. It is also necessary to address the issue of the status of informal carers - people who decide to take care of their family members themselves, of which there are 80% on the territory of the European Union.  We need to be understanding about situations where helping a family member and him or her family member become a full-time job. This work is not easy, on the contrary, it requires complete dedication and dedication to another person. Indeed, it is a full-time job that as such must be recognised, regulated and valued.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. – In the EU, three-quarters of carers are women. This shows a very unequal situation, which is the result of unfair patriarchal structures and condemns millions of women to much more limited access to work than men, not to mention the associated stereotypes that reinforce the idea that we must first and foremosm be at home and deal exclusively with care tasks. In the face of this, the EU has treaties and a whole set of directives that can develop and improve on family and labour reconciliation and recognition of rights to caregivers. We therefore call on the Commission to support a programme and package of concrete measures, including the extension of maternity leave, to promote equality and real reconciliation. In addition, we want States to get involved by provide quality public services and key infrastructures, such as day centres or day care centres, with particular emphasis on rural areas or more punishable by depopulation. Finally, let us not forget to increase the provision of resources to cohesion policy to strengthen the provision of quality and public care services.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral reply to the Commission on Lyme disease (borreliosis) by Alojz Peterle, Daciana Octavia Sârbu, Jadwiga Wiśniewska, Frédérique Ries, Merja Kyllönen, Michèle Rivasi, Mireille D'Ornano, Sylvie Goddyn, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000088/2018 - B8-0417/2018) (2018/2774(RSP)).

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for the opportunity to put this oral question to the Commission on Lyme disease on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. There is no factual information on the prevalence of Lyme disease. Prevalence figures are based on guesswork and vary greatly depending on the source. In many countries, Lyme disease is still not recorded in any way and is of great importance for the seriousness of Lyme disease and, for example, for the allocation of research appropriations. There are a wide range of different views on Lyme disease treatment practices. Lyme disease is primarily treated with antibiotics. In general, it is agreed that the best treatment results are obtained when treatment can be started at an early stage. In contrast, differing views differ from each other on the dosage of the drug, the length of treatment period and the treatment of chronic Lyme disease. The symptoms of those with Lyme disease are very individual and some of the diseases are associated with severe additional infections. There may be a number of problems with antibody tests, such as the fact that the production of antibodies has not yet started because it is too short a time since the infections or because the antibodies are bound to immuno-complexes. The study of Lyme disease and related additional infections is currently woefully inadequate. The effectiveness of the various treatments should be started very quickly to explore more extensively. An important research topic is also the chronicisation of Lyme disease. Patients whose symptoms persist even after long courses of antibiotics are unfortunately often left without rehabilitation and treatment. And their fitness and ability to work have often been lost for a long time, even permanently. Little progress has already been made, as Lyme neuroborreliosis has been added to infectious diseases covered by epidemiological surveillance, but more and more efforts are needed to combat Lyme disease and to raise awareness of Lyme disease. It must be possible to harmonise and improve the treatment practices of the Member States and, above all, to improve access to care for patients, clients. In addition, diagnostics need to be refined and we would like to have a vaccine against Lyme Lyme Lyme Lyme disease one day. With regard to the above problems, the challenges, we would like to kindly ask the Commission for answers, solutions, plans for the future and ideas on this matter. Unfortunately, the number of ticks is growing very strongly in Europe and their geographical prevalence is constantly expanding. This is thought to be due to the climate mildening brought about by climate change. Even in northern Europe, frosty winters are soon a rarity, and this especially favors ticks and their host animals. In this respect, therefore, the future does not look any better, quite the opposite. The number of people with Lyme disease is expected to continue to increase. That is why we hope for rapid action to rectify this. Finally, I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on the Environment and throughout parliament for their very good cooperation and strong support. I would like to thank both the International Association for Lyme Lyme Lyme and the national associations for their work in improving the status of people with Lyme disease, and in particular I would like to thank our Irish colleague, Liadh Ní Riada, who has been valiantly addressing this issue for years. Fortunately, now we have got the whole team from the Environment Committee involved in this work. Thank you for that. Working together to move forward.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Lyme disease, or Borreliosis, is a real health concern for European citizens, who are increasingly exposed to ticks and the associated risks of Lyme disease. In fact, Lyme disease is the most prevalent tick-transmitted infection in Europe.  Recent studies estimate that the incidence of Lyme disease at 22 cases per 100 000 persons per year, with a steadily increasing occurrence in several Member States. In the absence of a consistent surveillance system in the past, it remains difficult to accurately assess the overall trend of Lyme disease. It is, however, clear that the northward spread of ticks and adaptation of altitude are associated with climate change and land-use change.  Currently, there is no vaccine against Lyme disease so the recommendation is to take general prevention methods, such as tick awareness, appropriate clothing in tick-infested areas and the removal of attached ticks. These are particularly important for citizens living in areas where Lyme disease is endemic and high-risk groups, such as agricultural and forestry workers. Let me now address each of the questions you raised. Question one: the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and Member State experts worked on a proposal to include Lyme disease on the EU list of notifiable diseases. However, the diagnosis of Lyme disease is challenging, as the symptoms are varied and often non—specific. In addition, different diagnostic criteria and tests are used in different countries. Thus, the disease may go undetected, with the subsequent risk of developing serious chronic manifestations. Neuroborreliosis is the most serious complication of the Borrelia bacterial infection, seen in about 10% of patients with Lyme disease. The definition of neuroborreliosis is more standardised than other Lyme disease manifestations, with the possibility to confirm cases based on a common EU case definition.  This is why, based on a scientific assessment, it was therefore decided to include Lyme neuroborreliosis in the list of EU notifiable diseases under the decision on serious cross—border threats to health. The Commission remains fully committed to tackle the disease, working with Member States to strengthen prevention, surveillance and control of Lyme disease. As a key element, the decision on serious cross—border threats to health, which I have just mentioned, provides for epidemiological surveillance of communicable diseases through the use of comparable and compatible data. Question two: with the recent inclusion of Lyme neuroborreliosis in the list of EU notifiable diseases, all EU and EEA Member States are required to report such cases using the standard EU case definition. The epidemiological information on neuroborreliosis will be collected by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, starting in 2019 for cases diagnosed in 2018. In time, this will allow a better evaluation of the disease prevalence and trend of Lyme disease in Europe. Cooperation on surveillance, prevention and control between Member States is ongoing, coordinated by the centre. Question three: the centre is actively contributing to enhance awareness about Lyme disease among professionals and the general population. Several publications and tools are available, including information about the disease and the vector infographics disease fact-sheets for professionals and health practitioners and a communication toolkit on tick-borne diseases and preventive measures against tick bites. To strengthen preparedness and exchange of best practices, the Commission organised a workshop on the challenges of managing outbreaks of vector-borne diseases in September 2017. The centre has also conducted community preparedness case studies, including on Lyme disease, focusing on synergies on community and hospitals. Question four: as regards diagnostic practices, reporting of Lyme neuroborreliosis cases from 2018 onwards will be done according to a common case definition and diagnostic criteria. This will help to allow for a more accurate picture of the prevalence of Lyme disease in the EU. In addition, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control has conducted a systematic literature review on the diagnostic accuracy of serological tests for Lyme disease. It will start collecting data on the laboratory methods to evaluate the diagnosis for Lyme neuroborreliosis in 2019.  Question five: as you know, the Commission is not in a position to harmonise treatment practices as this falls within the competence of the Member States. This being said, the Commission is committed to help develop new and better diagnostics for Lyme disease. This effort has seen significant financial support in recent years. Question six: let me highlight that there is indeed currently very significant funding behind efforts to improve the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of Lyme disease in the EU. The Commission has recently supported research on improved diagnostics that will permit early and accurate diagnosis of Lyme disease through the provision of EUR 7.8 million. It is also worth noting that, in 2016, the European Investment Bank granted EUR 25 million for the development of a Lyme vaccine. Additionally, the Commission has provided EUR 3 million to fund the development of an anti-tick vaccine aiming to protect against all tick-borne diseases in Europe. The remaining two years of Horizon 2020, and in particular its forthcoming calls for research and innovation project proposals, will offer further opportunities to support research on Lyme disease. We now need to implement a robust Lyme disease surveillance to have a clearer picture on the disease burden and trends across the EU. We will further focus on awareness raising, improving community preparedness and prevention and supporting research efforts to develop new diagnostic methods and vaccines. I hope, and indeed trust, you share the intention to drive matters forward, to strengthen prevention and reduce the prevalence and the suffering associated with Lyme disease.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – Mr President. Dear Commissioner, colleagues and colleagues, I am pleased that today we are debating and voting on Lim Lyme disease, which is becoming a growing health challenge.  I am grateful to Commissioner Jourova for the Commission's comprehensive response. I come from Slovenia, which is part of the European and world summit on disease disease, and I have personal experience with it.  Lyme disease is a bacterial disease that is difficult to detect, diagnose and treat in a timely manner. Thus, many patients receive misdiagnosis and therapies. The number of sufferers is increasing and climate change is accelerating the spread of the disease. We don't have a vaccine registered yet to prevent the disease. We have very different practices across Member States, and patients are also at higher costs as a result.  A common approach at European Union level is needed. We need uniform databases, more joint research and uniform treatment guidelines. We therefore call on the Commission to draw up a European plan to combat Lyme disease.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you very much for your very intensive answer to our questions. In Lower Austria we had a deputy governor who was stabbed by a tick; the whole thing was not recognized in time, so in the end it led to him needing a heart transplant to survive at all. In order not to repeat this dramatic example too often in Europe, I believe that we need very specific plans to detect Lyme disease in good time, to have data so that we also know how we treat it, and, as you have also mentioned, research into vaccination is essential. What we also need is to educate the population. Not only those who have an intensive connection with forestry and agriculture, because there are already guidelines here, and a certain awareness has already been created here. But in the population, which has the right to spend their free time in nature, for example, there is often the false impression that vaccination against FSME, a viral disease that is also transmitted by the tick, provides general protection for tick bites. In other words, I believe that it is also entirely the responsibility of the Member States to invite people to spend their free time in nature, but to draw their attention to the dangers that lurk there. An FSME vaccine does not protect against Lyme disease.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Neuroboreliosis is the most common zoonotic disease in Europe. It currently suffers from an estimated one million citizens. Bite by an infected tick, as well as symptoms of Borreliosis can be unrecognizable, and this leads to very serious complications.  Since there is no vaccine for Lyme disease, intensive action is necessary. It is necessary to train doctors of first contact, to introduce preventive examinations, as well as a rapid treatment path for people working in the agro-forestry sector. It is necessary to exchange good practices and to carry out intensive and effective information campaigns in the regions most affected by the spread of neuroboresis. I call on the Commission to develop a European plan to combat Lyme disease.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, the courage of people with Lyme disease commands admiration, because it is a real wall that they often face in their journey of suffering. First of all, we note the misunderstanding of many non-specialist doctors who simply do not have the tools to detect this disease in time, which already affects a million Europeans, a figure that is constantly increasing, especially because of climate change. Patients also face another obstacle: the conservatism of medical academies. In many cases, they continue to claim today that the Elisa test would be 100% reliable, while all scientific literature shows the opposite. In our text, we denounce this hostage-taking of patients, who have the right to benefit from totally reliable tests. It is therefore essential to take ownership of existing best practices, with good management of patients suffering from chronic Lyme disease, as is the case in Germany and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. This is clearly what all european associations, which are hundreds on the ground, are asking us to do. At home in Wallonia, I am thinking especially of Sonia Boulanger, who coordinates the nonprofit Time for Lyme. There is hope , as has already been discussed in this debate, doors are opening. The European Union has just added Lyme borreliosis to the list of communicable diseases, which is essential to network researchers. WHO has recently changed the codes of Lyme disease in the international classification of diseases, recognizing related dementia and mother-to-child transmission. To conclude in one word, we said that it is essential to fund Lyme disease research, because its diagnosis is complex and its clinical forms are varied. In the ten seconds I have left, I will remind you of this: a gesture, a habit, a card, a tick clamp for parents and for children could already, to begin with, avoid many complications.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, thank you for the answers you have given us at the Commission level. I welcome this resolution, which finally takes into account the suffering of these sick people. There was talk of "therapeutic wandering." I do not know if you know, but, as my colleague Frédérique Ries pointed out, this disease is often very poorly understood, because it has a chronic form and is not addressed at all in doctors' programmes and trainings. A form of denial surrounds this disease that does not fit into the codes. This explains, for example, that in France, patients go to Germany. As you propose, better harmonization is indeed necessary, because effective diagnostic means are absolutely necessary. Just because the tests are negative doesn't mean the disease isn't present. Similarly, we need to create working groups, as you have proposed, to set up an exchange of good practices, both on diagnosis, screening and treatment. Some countries refuse to treat patients with a high dose of antibiotics. And then there is the training of doctors, who are often unfamila in environmental health problems. Finally, research should be increased, funding increased and recognition of this disease as a occupational disease improved. So the stakes are high. But Europe can add value to establish the state of affairs, to better understand this disease and, of course, to better treat it.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Mr President, Commissioner, the reliability of serological tests and unconventional treatments for Lyme disease is of concern and should, in my view, have been addressed in this oral question. I also note the lack of references to the phenomenon of medical wandering in which some patients find themselves, as well as to the cross-border movements of patients seeking treatment for this disease. We could also have asked whether the Commission intended to encourage campaigns to raise awareness of the risks associated with Lyme disease as a result of tick bites, including the fact that the infection manifests itself with a time lag and has a wide variety of symptoms. Finally, why not hold the Commission to account for the scientific findings following the multi-million dollar investment in disease research and vaccine development? It is the role of elected officials to know where public money goes.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the explosion in the number of Cases of Lyme disease shows a double fracture. Let us first highlight the territorial and social divide, since the most widespread zoonotic disease in Europe affects the inhabitants of rural areas above all, which probably explains the lack of interest of the public authorities and the difficult recognition of this condition as a occupational disease. In my region, in France, many very young men who work on apple trees, for example, suffer from this dramatic disease. Some cases are really very difficult and get worse until dementia. It's really a lot of pain. The divide then separates man and nature, since the hunt for predators, although essential to the ecosystem, will in its wake carry the proliferation of certain parasites. A recent study demonstrated the role of foxes, sometimes considered harmful, in the eradication of ticks. However, at a time when between 650,000 and 850,000 Europeans are affected each year by this pathology, the true journey of the combatant inflicted on so many patients facing the shortcomings of modern medicine cannot be tolerated. Beyond a vast joint effort at European level, these patients deserve above all our listening and above all our respect.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, they are smaller than a pinhead, but they are wreaking havoc. Ticks are the leading vector of animal diseases in the world, the second for human diseases, after the mosquito. This is a real public health issue. It has already been said that more and more people are suffering from this disease because, unfortunately, it is largely under-diagnosed and sometimes asymptomatic. There is no consensus on its diagnosis or treatment. This lack of recognition has permanently affected patients with this disease, who find themselves in a situation of diagnostic and therapeutic wandering. We must first think of them, because beyond the simple flu-like symptoms that can develop in the first phase of the disease, an infection with the bacterium Borrelia can, if abused, become chronic and disabling. So it's a pathology that needs to be taken seriously. I have heard your proposals, Commissioner. There is an urgent need to intensify research efforts and a vaccine must be developed as soon as possible. But prevention is also essential. We need to better inform citizens about how to protect themselves from tick bites and the need for testing after a bite. With Lyme borreliosis present throughout Europe, we are facing a real cross-border challenge that requires coordinated European action.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Mr President, each and every one of us can get Lyme disease, borreliosis. A single walk in the forest is enough. Lyme disease can have serious health consequences: paralysis, joint infections or heart problems. Everyone knows that ticks transmit Lyme disease to humans. But ticks, how do they get Lyme disease? It is through small rodents, such as mice, that ticks catch borreliosis, or Lyme disease. That's where the hero of my story comes in: the fox. Indeed, the more foxes there are, the less mice and small rodents come out of their hole and circulate, and the less the disease spreads. I appeal to you, ladies and gentlemen, to let our natural ecosystem do, let the fox live and above all let it do its job, because it contributes in large part to the prevention of Lyme disease.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that we can be satisfied with the work that has been done to achieve this resolution on Lyme disease, which was, as you know, highly anticipated by many associations of patients. Every year, nearly one million Europeans would be affected by this disease, many of whom remain uncertain and medically unsatisfactory. We know that the proliferation of ticks and the increase in bites are directly responsible for the extent of this disease. Ticks once confined to forests and mountains are now proliferating into peri-urban areas and threatening much larger populations. That is why action is urgently needed at our level, because this rural disease has long suffered from inaction, lack of resources and lack of public interest. I am therefore pleased that today we are reacting collectively to the challenge of fighting this disease. Even more, I hear the voices of the sick and the families who will see in our approach the hope of finally being heard and properly taken care of by the medical world. That is why we must support this resolution.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, the increase in Lyme disease is of great concern and it is a major problem. There is no European consensus on treatment, and diagnosis and screening of Lyme disease is not on the agenda and national practices vary considerably.  Unnecessarily many patients do not have access to the treatment that is appropriate for them or do not get the correct diagnosis immediately. I also speak from my own experience from our own family: my cousin had the effects of Lyme disease and its bacterial infection last summer. He went to the doctor. The family went to the GP and the GP just says to this boy, "You just have the flu, go home." In the end – he almost died – it was still going well.  But these consequences are also being discussed in Austria, and we must work with each other immediately. Because even general practitioners don't know what's going on. I therefore welcome the European Commission's executive decision to include Lyme borreliosis in the list of communicable diseases. Now let us now recognise this terrible disease as an occupational disease and promote research and awareness in order to prevent the disease. But not only that, the whole family, our whole environment wondered: what are we going to do about it? It's not just people who work in nature. It's kids who cycle, even from cities. It's the citizens too! It simply requires a national approach and thanks for your instigation.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Mr President, Lyme disease or a thousand-face disease, which affects the whole body, is the most common and widespread tick-borne condition in Europe. Our concern about the prevalence of Lyme disease in Europe is contained in this resolution. We welcome the inclusion of Lyme disease on the European list of communicable diseases, which will enable patients to benefit from a robust and structured health system for the rapid and reliable identification of Lyme boreliosis cases in the European Union, as well as mutual assistance in the analysis and interpretation of the data collected.  However, we must also note that this disease with a thousand faces requires additional funding from those allocated by the European Union so far, with a view to increasing research efforts for early detection, diagnosis and treatment of boreliosis. We also need more information and awareness-raising campaigns for people at high risk of disease, as well as campaigns to disseminate best practices for diagnosing and detecting Lyme disease.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, Lyme disease is one of 10 diseases that afflict humans as a result of contact with ticks. Sometimes there can be two simultaneous infections. There has been a 400% increase in Lyme disease in the UK in the last four years. Good livestock farming practices can make an immense beneficial difference here by reducing tick numbers, yet the Green lobby, with its naive ideas of re-wilding, want to remove the livestock entirely. Between them, sheep as teeth grazers and cattle as tongue grazers can prevent grasses from becoming damp and rank and thus deny the ticks a habitat. Meanwhile, the farmers also control the bracken, another favourite tick habitat. Any ticks that do appear will attach themselves to these animals and will be dealt with by the routine application of recommended insecticides.  Twenty years ago, this involved the use of potentially dangerous organophosphorus compounds. Now, thanks to the research efforts of large companies, safer products which are simple to apply will readily destroy ticks. In the absence of these livestock, the ticks will multiply and settle on ground-nesting birds in fatally large numbers, yet the Green lobby will tell you that it’s farmers who threaten bird numbers. Unlike grass, ticks do not thrive in heather, which is an alternative feed for sheep. However, the Green lobby frown on attempts to re-establish heather because of its association with politically incorrect grouse shooting. So we have a choice: a thriving tick-free upland economy based on livestock heather and grouse on the one hand, or the Green lobby’s paradise of abandoned land, welfare payments, tick-infested wildlife and human disease.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Thank you, President. I hope that members of the medical profession are listening to this debate, because it has been quite interesting that, across the House from all Member States, what we are hearing from patients is that they are not being listened to when they visit their general practitioner. That is perhaps  because there isn’t sufficient awareness of the myriad symptoms of Lyme disease, but we certainly need greater awareness among the first port of call, which is the medical practitioners in the local clinics. I want to compliment Tick Talk Ireland. They have been tirelessly campaigning to raise awareness about this disease. They want patient—centric best practices, and we support them in that. I have read some terrible stories of people who are suffering chronic conditions because of Lyme disease misdiagnosis and lack of treatment. This is a really important debate; it is about the health of our citizens, and I want to thank the Commission for the answers you have given to our questions today.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the debate has shown that Lyme disease or borrelosis is a dangerous bacterial disease caused by the tick bite infected with this bacterium. It affects humans and animals, and the fact that we have 850 000 cases a year shows how serious this issue is. This is a occupational disease that affects farmers as well as forest farmers, and I think we now need to take concrete steps, because treatment methods need to be strengthened. There must be an exchange of best practices between Member States. In addition, doctors' training is required, as well as the use of clinical examinations. At the same time, I think that money should be given for further research in this area in order to tackle the disease, which is particularly dangerous – according to the World Health Organisation – as it is transmitted from mother to foetus. I think very specific measures are needed.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, last Sunday week in my own town, Killarney, there was a group from the Men’s shed – a hundred of them – and they got the European Citizens Prize this year. They came to help control the rhododendron, which is a beautiful plant but is invasive in our National Park. Also in our National Park, we have a very famous herd of deer, and as part of the preparation for their work, they were given an outline on Lyme disease and what steps they should take to ensure they wouldn’t go back home with it, and I think one of the key points mentioned there was that within 48 hours one is safe enough if a tick attaches itself to your body and it’s removed. I think that’s the key point here. We must create awareness and encourage people to check their bodies, especially if they are in parks where there are deer, etc., and remove the tick promptly. That will ensure that nothing will happen. So I welcome what the Commissioner has said in creating awareness and research, etc., because there’s up to a million people affected in Europe and we need to help them.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Ticks are a creeping epidemic. Every year, around 800 000 Europeans are affected by Lyme disease, and this creates great human suffering. There is an explanation for why tick-borne diseases such as TBE and Lyme disease are on the rise. Ticks love humid and warm weather, and that's what climate change brings us. Climate change is moving faster and is more widespread in our northern part of the world. Ticks are effective carriers, and their spread is affected by climate change. The problem of a warmer climate and the spread of ticks goes hand in hand with other health problems. With extreme weather, bacteria spread not only in water, but also in food. New diseases and viral infections are spreading in Europe. That is why we need a common European strategy to deal with this silent epidemic of Lyme disease. This is a symptom of the great challenge we face: to stop climate change and to live up to the Paris Agreement.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am primarily concerned with security issues, including, of course, health security, the possibility of terrorists or totalitarian states using various elements of biological weapons. I will tell you right away that there is no doubt: Lyme disease is not interesting in terms of its potential for use in biological attacks. Unfortunately, I am once again observing that we are also characterised by inconsistency, lack of determination, lack of coherence and isolation of individual subjects, which, I stress, have a common denominator. I will draw attention to the shortcomings in education, the information gaps, the shortcomings in diagnosis, as confirmed by the Commissioner. I want to make it clear that citizens of the European Union need passports and visas, but unfortunately they do not. Today we have the problem of moving measles from Ukraine to the west, for example to Polish. I draw attention to this, because tolerating such phenomena can unfortunately cause serious risks.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Merje Kyllönen, who brought this issue here to plenary, and as it turns out, it is a subject that goes across Europe that goes across political groups. It's a topic we all want to address. We can, of course, address it by telling each other in Europe that we know it exists, but we should address it above all by linking our health capacities and, above all, by changing the common view in the European Union today on how to treat, diagnose or screen for Lyme disease. The problem is simply that the diagnosis of the disease does not happen in the time we need. Patients are very often referred for some other banal treatment that doesn't work, and then the really expert treatment takes place only when there's actually not much help anymore and there are a number of other problems. I would therefore like to ask and thank the Commissioner very much for saying that we will generally look at examining this disease better, looking better for causes, but also seeking better treatment.
