I beg her, let's give it some money, it just won't work without them, and if we don't find them, we don't have a chance to change that.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, and apologies, I’m just arriving, we were at a vote in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs but I thank you for this one minute. Commissioner, my office has been listening to your responses and, I have to say, I’m not fully satisfied with your response on the need for a proper, harmonised approach to diagnosis. The truth is that many people who have Lyme disease are undiagnosed and this is a double whammy for people who suffer from this most debilitating disease. I know in Ireland many patients have to go abroad so that they can be properly tested. It’s very expensive for them, many of them have suffered for many years and they cannot get a diagnosis in Ireland. Specialists and doctors will tell them: clinically, the results say you’re fine. They go abroad and they get a diagnosis of Lyme disease. I believe that the EU can act in a much stronger way by strongly encouraging a harmonised, accurate test for Lyme disease so that all EU citizens can have access to timely and accurate diagnosis.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Dear Chairman, I am pleased that this issue has come on the agenda because, indeed, Lyme disease poses a great danger to health. As we know, symptoms are sometimes noticed very late and the problem is with diagnostics. We must do everything, as Ms. Jourová said, to work on researching this disease, not only diseases but also vaccines. We heard there's no vaccine and that's the basic problem. We have heard that there are different practices in different countries, so we need to level the treatment practices.  I think it's necessary to find a vaccine. You mentioned Horizon research, I think it's the way to the finish line, but of course it doesn't hurt to mention here the climate changes that made up or favored that there are more and more carriers, i.e. ticks and that on large agricultural areas and forests they are really problems.  So we have to do everything to protect our citizens, i.e. patients, but also to make it easier for GPs to get diagnostics and, if we succeed, to find a vaccine.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I have listened with great interest to the views during this discussion, and I am grateful for all your valuable insights and interest to address the burden of Lyme disease in Europe.  Allow me to repeat that the emphasis now should be on implementation and concrete action to support Member States in their efforts. With the recent inclusion of Lyme neuroborreliosis in the list of EU notifiable diseases, we will strengthen surveillance across the EU using a common EU case definition and diagnostic criteria.  This will lead to a more accurate assessment of the disease burden and trends of Lyme disease in Europe. We will continue to raise awareness at EU, national and community levels, among both the public and health professionals. Here, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control has a key role to play.  Finally, the development of new and better diagnostics and vaccines will be further supported through the framework programme for research and innovation, Horizon 2020 and through other available instruments. I once again thank you for your interest in this issue and look forward to working closely together towards achieving strengthened surveillance, earlier diagnosis and, ultimately, prevention of this disease. (Applause)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I have received, in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure, a motion for a resolution. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 15 October 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Czesław HOC
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "You can say, "It's about time!" A European Parliament resolution on Lyme neuroboresis (Lyme disease) was adopted. Finally, Europe has issued a fight against the most common tick-fighting disease. Around 1 million citizens currently suffer from Lyme disease in Europe. It has been calculated that, if a reliable early diagnosis of Lyme disease is established and thus a marked reduction in cases of advanced disease, we will save around EUR 330 million in healthcare costs in the first 5 years! More importantly, we will spare the suffering of many people! We must also bear in mind that Lyme disease is a occupational disease of foresters and farmers. It's also a compensation cost! Therefore, as a matter of urgency, a European plan to combat this silent epidemic should be introduced, a European Lyme disease network should be set up, thus introducing a separate ICD (International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Health Problems) for early and late-stage disease, introducing preventive studies, rapid and reliable identification of Lyme disease cases in the Union, establishing a fast track of therapy according to EBM (evidence-based medicine) and introducing permanent European monitoring.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – Lyme borreliosis is a bacterial disease caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdoferi, which is transmitted to humans by a bite of ticks that are also contaminated with bacteria. Lyme disease is an infectious disease of humans and some gardens of domestic and wild animals that are transmitted by ticks. There are around 650 000-850 000 estimated cases in Europe and geographically there is a higher incidence in Central Europe. The infection occurs in the spring and summer period (from April to October) therefore boreliosis is recognized as an occupational disease of farmers, forestry workers and researchers on the ground in the countries where it is present. The EU expresses concern about the worrying extent of the spread of Lyme disease in the European population, as the methods used have shown that around 1 million citizens suffer from the disease. So far, the Union has allocated major research funding on early detection and future treatment of Lyme boreliosis (up to €16 million through projects such as ANTIDotE, ID-LYME and LYMEDIADEX). It is of utmost importance to continue to work on fundamental knowledge of the mechanism that turns Lyme disease into a chronic disease, so this Report calls for mandatory reporting in all Member States affected by Lyme disease.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Vietnam, in particular the situation of political prisoners (2018/2925(RSP)).

name: Marek JUREK
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Communist states often evolve, many of us know this best, because they have seen it in their lifetime, but communism is communism, and unfortunately in our relations with countries that have such governments, we must always pay attention to the need to move away from this ideology. In Vietnam, systematic persecution of Christians continues, sometimes very drastic. Pastor Nguyen Trung Ton was sentenced to 12 years in prison, is ill, the family has no possibility of contact with him, and in the absence of treatment his life is really seriously threatened. Churches are demolished, it is forbidden to print the Bible in the language of national minorities, for example, Muongs. But here it is also worth paying attention to what is happening elsewhere in East Asia. In China, persecution of the Church is also on the rise. Bishop Peter Shao Zhumin was recently arrested, as were four of his priests. I would ask the Commissioner to take a position on this issue, because silence will be... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the In Vietnam, we are seeing an increase in arbitrary arrests and politically motivated condemnations of human rights and environmental activists, lawyers and bloggers. Anyone who wants to express their opinion freely, those who criticise abuses or use the right to freedom of assembly, must expect persecution and arrest. I was AFET rapporteur for the partnership agreement with Vietnam, whose human rights protection requirements also apply to the free trade agreement. It is essential that the EU formulates clear benchmarks for human rights protection that Vietnam must meet before the free trade agreement is agreed. These include, in particular, the immediate release of political prisoners, the revision of the penal code and the ratification of ILO agreements 87, 98 and 105. The EU must speak out clearly about human rights violations in Vietnam and also support civil society on the ground through process monitoring and prison visits.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, when we talk about Vietnam, we are reminded of images from the bloody war with the Americans, bombs and arms, but in reality the war against the enemy has turned into a war on dissent. In the country of South-East Asia, if you express a contrary opinion, especially on human rights or environmental rights, you end up in a cell, and that is where mistreatment, beatings, electroshocks, injections of substances begin. And what do we do to respond to all this? We reward Vietnam with a nice trade deal. So the response of this Parliament must be there, in denying this trade agreement, in responding in practice to the human rights violations that are taking place in that country.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Author. Mr President, the human rights situation in Vietnam is worrying. While the European Union has been negotiating a trade agreement with Vietnam since 2012, the situation is deteriorating by the day. The crackdown on freedom of expression and the condemnation of any political criticism of the government is intensifying. Bloggers, pro-democracy activists, social and environmental rights activists are prosecuted, abused, tortured, arbitrarily arrested, sentenced to long sentences up to the death penalty. Is it worth remembering that this country executed, on average, 147 people per year between 2013 and 2016? In this context, we call on the Vietnamese authorities to release political prisoners and activists, to pass the laws necessary to guarantee freedom of expression, to ratify and respect ILO conventions, including freedom of association. We also call on the Commission to take this disastrous human rights situation into account in the discussions on the trade agreement.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, a staggering 160 human rights activists are in prison in Vietnam, reflecting the systematic repression in the country: from free expression to freedom of belief, all the way to the abysmal prison conditions and the application of the death penalty. We call on the Vietnamese authorities to respect human rights and to release those only detained for exercising their human rights. We urge access for UN special rapporteurs on human rights defenders, the Working Group on Arbitrary Detention and the UN Special Rapporteur for freedom of expression. We remind the Vietnamese authorities that human rights are a clear conditionality when it comes to trade relations. And I wanted to specifically zoom in on freedom of expression, online and offline, given the fact that Vietnam ranks 175th out of 180 countries on the Reporters Without Borders’ list of press freedom in the world. They really have to start respecting the rights of freedom of expression, online and offline, and the least we can do in Europe is to stop the export of surveillance systems that are used to track and trace human rights defenders.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Author. – Mr President, Vietnam is a dynamically developing country with a promising future ahead of it. But, as in China, there are massive violations of human rights and freedoms under Communist Party rule. We also see a similar paradox to other so-called communist systems – the absence of trade unions, massive violations of workers' rights, or the media's dependence on political actors.  The Reporters Without Borders index shows that media dependence on the Communist Party has even increased in 2018. A free press practically does not exist, and in most cases any independent speech in the media is punishable by imprisonment. I would also like to mention that the death penalty is still a topical issue in Vietnam, and all the more alarming is the fact that Vietnam is keeping the number of death row inmates secret from the international community. These are serious facts on which we cannot remain silent. Getting China to do something is difficult, but in the case of Vietnam, we have a tool in our hands. The signing of a free trade agreement between the European Union and Vietnam is coming. In this resolution, the European Parliament shows that it is not indifferent to the situation of political prisoners, bloggers, activists, Christian clerics and the masses of the population monitored by the regime using modern technologies. The European Parliament will insist on improvements on the part of Vietnam, otherwise it will not give its consent to the trade agreement. Paradoxically, Vietnam is a very close country to me, because there are 100,000 Vietnamese living in the Czech Republic, the largest community in Europe. I would therefore like the European Union to have good economic relations with Vietnam. But it won't work without conditions. I am also glad that there is a great consensus across political parties in the European Parliament.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I condemn the types of practices mentioned in this resolution and call on the Vietnamese authorities to release anyone it has imprisoned for exercising their fundamental right. I would also call for the criminal code to be reassessed and any laws which restrict these basic undertakings.  In my opinion, Vietnam should ratify all human rights treaties of the United Nations, and cannot be seen to take human rights seriously until having done so. At the same time, having visited Vietnam a couple of years ago on a mission on behalf of INTA, I know Vietnam to be a wonderful, beautiful country with exceptionally nice and decent people.  But I must stand up to this injustice and insist that it stop occurring. The relationship between the EU and Vietnam is a great one but full respect of the fundamental rights to freedom of expression, association, and peaceful assembly must be respected on both sides and the EU should work with Vietnam to ensure this can happen.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, with the EU-Vietnam trade and investment agreements on the table, we need to be more serious about the ‘essential elements’ clauses. Domestic repression has worsened in Vietnam. Human rights activists and bloggers not only face surveillance, intimidation and arbitrary arrest, but long stints in pre-trial detention, solitary confinements and excessive sentences. So Commissioner, I’d like you to clarify a couple of points, please. In terms of, firstly, what concrete human rights improvements has Vietnam made following the FTA negotiations? Secondly, how will the Commission ensure that Vietnam amends its repressive legal framework, in particular the penal code, the law on cyber security, bringing it into full compliance with international human rights standards? Thirdly, besides pressing Vietnam to release political prisoners, has the EU pushed for establishment of an Independent Police Complaints Commission to investigate grievances and provide oversight over these authorities?

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, much has been said in this debate and every now and then we have to look in the mirror. Of course, a free trade agreement is very important for the dynamism and development of a country like Vietnam, for the prosperity of its people.   But do we not always repeat that free trade and a free society must go hand in hand? Do people crave freedom, too, and especially not for freedom? Do you answer honestly: has the Government of Vietnam already shown enough in your view that it is taking concrete steps to put an end to the massive human rights violations and repression?  The facts: journalists, human rights defenders, bloggers, clerics, political activists, they end up in jail for the least critical sound. I specifically mention Hoang Duc Binh, Nguyen Nam Phong, Nguyen Trung Truc and Le Dinh Luong. They must be released, as do hundreds of others.  I therefore urge the Commission to continue to remind Vietnam of its obligations during the human rights dialogue.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the European communist regimes collapsed in 1989, two years before the USSR in turn disappeared. Nevertheless, there are still some communist regimes in the world, such as Vietnam, which is a dinosaur. The Vietnamese Constitution proclaims, I quote, that "the Communist Party, the vanguard of the working class, is the force that runs the state and society". The National Assembly and the judiciary are therefore at his command. Vietnam has been seeking to integrate into international society for 20 years, so it joined ASEAN in 1995, APEC in 1998, the WTO in 2007 and signed a partnership agreement with the European Union in 2012. Despite this, Vietnam remains a dictatorship that imprisons its political opponents, such as Mr. Dinh Luong, who was sentenced to 20 years in prison on 16 August. However, the French Prime Minister has just praised President Ho Chi Minh, founder of this communist dictatorship, in exchange for signing commercial contracts. The European Union could have saved European honour, but it will not, because it is about to sign a free trade agreement with Vietnam. Soon European consumers will be able to buy products made by Vietnamese political prisoners at a low price.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, Vietnam is actually reducing its citizens' freedom in every area. There are over 100 human rights defenders languishing in jail, often in awful conditions, and the new cyber security law will give authorities more tools to silence dissent. It might surprise Members that despite all this, the EU is accelerating the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement process, pushing for a swift implementation. This Parliament must make it clear that we will not ratify this unless there is solid progress on human rights. The EU risks losing its credibility, if on the one hand it withdraws trade preferences with Cambodia over human rights abuses, and on the other hand, it signs a trade agreement with one of the most repressive states in Southeast Asia. Therefore, I urge Vietnam to release political prisoners, bring its legislation in line with international human rights standards, halt all executions and ratify the ILO conventions, and I call on the EU to strengthen their efforts to ensure concrete human rights improvements in Vietnam. The EU trade policy was designed as a tool to promote human rights in third countries and, Mr President, we must use it as such.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the ongoing conflict in the East China Sea must lead our States to act with the utmost caution. We are entangled between the United States, which is blowing on embers, the states of the region, which are reararing, and China, which is investing heavily in its navy. The situation is becoming extremely critical and we face a risk of major conflict. I have always fought communism and have no fondness for the Hanoi regime. I find the persecution of Vietnamese Catholics particularly intolerable. It is not bombastic proclamations, but discreet and resolute diplomatic actions by our States that can stop them. But in Asia, we always negotiate with respect for the national sovereignty of our interlocutors. It would be enough to reject the trade agreement, the product of your ideology and which also delivers our economies to the ferocious dumping of a country without rules, to obtain concessions and obtain greater democracy. So why don't you go in that direction? So, once again, act with caution and firmness!

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have not signed this resolution, but of course it will vote in favour. I did not sign up because I believe that the authors of such a resolution should be well versed in all the details and know more about each point than is justified. It will, of course, vote in favour of this resolution primarily because of three points: J, K and M, which include the rights of NGOs, the rights of journalists, the activities of free media. Reporters Without Borders themselves write that the country deserves special attention because of the worst working conditions for journalists and free media. Let me remind you: this is probably the 175th or 176th state out of 180 assessed when it comes to journalists' rights to practise. For this reason, I would like to emphasise this appeal and the content of the resolution.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, it’s becoming increasingly difficult to ignore the human rights situation in Vietnam. Well, that’s for everyone except for our trade negotiators. Human rights defenders report a deteriorating situation on the ground, whether they be online bloggers, religious minorities or trade union leaders in shoe factories or in the fishing industries. In a country where basic freedoms such as the freedom of speech or religious rights are routinely denied to the population and where political opposition is systematically repressed and over 150 reported prisoners of conscience and human rights activists are currently detained in often terrible conditions, if the EU was serious about securing progress in terms of human and labour rights in Vietnam it would insist on the release of these prisoners and the pre-ratification of human rights and ILO core conventions as a precondition to our ratification of the trade and investment agreements. At the very least, the EU should articulate a series of tangible human rights benchmarks that Vietnam must meet before those agreements come before this House for approval. That’s at the very least – we need more, and we need better.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Vietnam is the new Eldorado. Multinationals are throwing parties. They have made investments, they are taking advantage of Vietnam's hunger wages and, of course, they are earning too much money. That is why there is also tolerance for promiscuity in the protection of labour rights in Vietnam and - much more so - tolerance, now, for oppression, for human rights violations, for the convictions of activists and for the mistreatment of prisoners, who do not even have access to a lawyer. It is a fact that Vietnam's penal code is not even compatible with international standards and, of course, oppression has also extended to Christian populations. A moratorium on the death penalty and, of course, tough measures against Vietnam are therefore needed. There cannot be this preferential treatment, with european Union cooperation tools and free trade, and this situation in Vietnam continues.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, expressing one's ideas has a price in Vietnam: giving up one's freedom and sometimes even one's life. This is well demonstrated by the case of Hoang Duc Binh, a well-known 34-year-old Vietnamese blogger. His denunciation of the environmental disaster caused by the Taiwanese company Formosa cost him dearly: the sentence of 14 years in prison.  The accusation: resistance to a public official and, you hear, abuse of democratic freedoms against the interests of the State. Paradoxical because abuse presupposes the full enjoyment of this freedom. However, the Vietnamese do not benefit at all, especially after the revision of the penal code, which even requires lawyers to report their own clients if they are guilty of certain crimes.  I ask you, ladies and gentlemen, what has changed since the agreements signed with a government that continues to forcefully suppress even the slightest dissent. A government which mocks the international conventions signed by it and which has now become a paradise for multinationals. Our demands are clear: immediate and unconditional release of all activists, journalists, prisoners of conscience and ordinary citizens. We demand full respect for human rights if these agreements are not waste paper. We cannot negotiate on that.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is a recurring case in this House to talk about Vietnam and, unfortunately, never for the best reasons, I might add. This time the rule is no exception and, once again, here we are debating the lack of freedom and democracy and the constant violation of human rights in Vietnam. This time, Commissioner, what brings us here is project 88's complaint that they are currently being shot, under subhuman conditions, at the sadly celebrated Vietnamese prisons, one hundred and sixty activists and that the Vietnamese authorities continue to arrest, persecute and intimidate human rights defenders, journalists, bloggers, human rights lawyers and civil society activists on an unprecedented scale. Commissioner, the Union cannot continue to agree with states that systematically violate their international commitments in the defence of human rights and which pursue those who express a different opinion from the official one. Therefore, Commissioner, it is of the most elementary justice and moral decency that the Union has called on the Vietnamese authorities to release, without exception, all political prisoners, under penalty of the cooperation and partnership agreement with Vietnam being compromised. We cannot, Commissioner, we cannot tolerate these abuses of human dignity anymore.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to stress that Vietnam has indeed made substantial progress over the past period, but it is important to remember that this is not really a free state, that it is by no means democratic in nature. If we are talking about one side where there is no opposition, there are no trade unions, if we are talking about the lack of media freedom, the absence of pluralistic views, on the contrary, even for a different opinion there are political prisoners, so it is clear that this is not a democratic character of the state, no one even doubts that. We have not only political prisoners here, but also religious prisoners. What can we do more? We have here the instrument of the trade agreement, I think we should put more pressure on the Vietnamese government. Of course, our diplomatic efforts, our delegation going to Vietnam, must talk about our basic reservations. We can talk, and that is why we should really be talking about these burning issues in these delegations, and I, of course, support this resolution.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union is closely following the human rights situation in Vietnam. Vietnam has made significant economic and social progress over the past twenty years, which resulted in a substantial advancement in socio-economic rights. However, I personally underline that we share your concerns, Parliament’s concerns, regarding political prisoners in the country. The frequent use of vaguely drafted national security provisions in Vietnam’s Penal Code results in numerous arrests, sentencing and detention of Vietnamese citizens who peacefully express their opinion both online and offline. As the European Union, we systematically discuss our concerns over limitations to freedom of expression and freedom of religion with authorities, including at the highest levels, calling on the Government to end persecution and harassment, and to release all peaceful advocates of human rights.  The continued harassment and detention of an increasing number of human rights defenders is systematically raised during our annual Human Rights Dialogue. This is also where we discuss a number of individual cases. Moreover in Hanoi, the EU regularly asks for the possibility to attend trials, to visit human rights defenders in prison or under house arrest, and insist on prisoners having access to legal counsel, medical care and, of course, family visits. We extend specific support to the Government in order to strengthen respect for human rights and the rule of law. We share best practices with selected ministries, provide input to the National Assembly on the legal framework including on the Penal Code, Labour Law and on Cybersecurity, and promote joint actions with like-minded partners and countries. Vietnam and the EU are committed to work towards a closer partnership by implementing the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and the Free Trade Agreement. No doubt, a key tool is the institutional and legally binding linkage between the Free Trade Agreement and the partnership and cooperation agreement ensuring that respect for human rights is an essential element of the trade relations. The European Union wants a prosperous Vietnam, a country that respects the rule of law and human rights and honours its international commitments. While firmly stating that the negative trend of restricting the right to freedom of expression needs to be reversed, the EU stands ready to engage with Vietnam to improve the human rights conditions in the country.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the end of the discussions. Written declarations (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – In Vietnam, human rights defenders and political activists face extreme hardships as they continue to be imprisoned, detained, and harassed by Vietnamese authorities. Currently an estimated 160 activists are serving prison sentences, according to the Vietnamese Political Prisoner Database. The freedom of press, expression and peaceful assembly, or the right to privacy are strongly restricted as aut6horities abuse the repressive provisions embedded in the Criminal Code of Vietnam. These actions directly contradict the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Vietnam acceded in 1982. Political intimidation, threats of prolonged prison sentences and the restrictions to freedoms are some factors resulting in Vietnam’s rank of 175 out of 180 on the 2018 Reporters Without Borders Press Freedom Index. The Vietnamese government needs to repeal all repressive laws, releasing human rights defenders and prisoners of conscious while providing them with appropriate medical and legal support in addition to trial monitoring. The comprehensive discussions between the EU and Vietnam in Human Rights Dialogue continue to be necessary as key instruments used to encourage Vietnam in the implementation of human rights reforms. The European Union must continue to press for concrete human rights improvements in Vietnam.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – Despite its economic progress, Vietnam’s human rights situation remains dire. Basic rights, including freedom of speech, opinion, press, association, and religion, are restricted, while the criminal justice system lacks independence. In its relations with Vietnam, the EU should pressure its important trading partner’s authorities to ease restrictions on civil and political rights and to act in defence of human rights activists calling for democracy and greater freedoms. In particular, it should firmly call on the Vietnamese authorities to immediately and unconditionally release all human rights defenders and prisoners of conscience detained or sentenced, including Hoang Duc Binh, Nguyen Nam Phong, Nguyen Trung Truc and Le Dinh Luong.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the human rights situation in Cuba (2018/2926(RSP)).

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Author. – Mr President, in 2002, 2005 and 2010, the European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize to Cuban human rights defenders. According to today's resolution, Cuba is still a totalitarian state of the only Communist Party that does not bother to respect fundamental human rights. Defenders of these rights, or only those who wish to express themselves or gather freely, are intimidated or unlawfully imprisoned. Only now in October have more than 200 Cubans been imprisoned in this way simply because they exercised their rights under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. State authorities do not allow the existence of human rights organisations and prevent the travel of their representatives. Freedom of religion exists in Cuba to a minimum, church leaders are under the supervision of state authorities. Cuba enforces censorship and does not allow the existence of media other than state media. This situation also calls partly to account us, the European Union and its Member States. We, for the new agreement with Cuba, did not insist on clear conditionality in its application by respect for fundamental rights. However, even this deficiency does not reduce our obligation in all the External Relations of the European Union to insist on respect for these rights, as imposed on us by Article 21(1) of the Treaty on European Union. It is there is no need to ensure that the provisions of the Treaty on European Union are It is therefore necessary to clearly stand up for the fundamental rights of Cubans, and to take advantage of all the economic opportunities opened up by the new treaty with Cuba. We must not be let down by holding elections in which independent candidates are not allowed to run. The contact with civil society must be strengthened as much as possible and all repressive methods applied by the Cuban State must be relentlessly pointed out.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, when the Obama administration broke the diplomatic stalemate with Cuba in 2014 and reopened the US embassy in Havana, there was much optimism in the West for a reset. But we now continue to watch with alarm as the new President, Miguel Diaz—Canel, sets out his vision for the country under its new constitution.  So far, sadly, there’s very little evidence from observers of any true progress in human rights in that country. Political rights and civil liberties continue to be repressed, with the regime choosing to use short—term incarceration as a strategy for intimidating dissidents. Although it’s thought that, overall, the number of political prisoners is decreasing, sadly, one of the first laws signed by the new President imposes punitive measures on artists and musicians who operate without prior authorisation. The Ladies in White, who won the Sakharov Prize in 2005, continue to be harassed. Thus, this is a mixed picture, so the EU must continue in its stick—and—carrot efforts to encourage the Cuban Government to transition towards a free and democratic state.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Author. – Mr President, I would like to remind you that Cuba was the only country in America with which the European Union had no relations, because for more than twenty years the European right, led by José María Aznar, prevented cooperation with the island through the Common Position. Now, under the excuse of urgency, the PP and one of its companies bring back the same arguments they used to make it difficult to approve the Political Dialogue Agreement between the European Union and Cuba. It's unreasonable.  It is unreasonable because, in these two years of agreement, just two years, the mechanism provided for in the Agreement has been put in place; because the efforts of the High Representative and Mr Lambrinidis have been to hold four — four – human rights dialogue meetings; which may seem bad to you, but this is the first time we've had a dialogue with the island about human rights.  You can also present some of your particular cases in the Delegation of the European Union in Cuba , led by one of the best European diplomats, Mr Alberto Navarro.  It is unreasonable what you do, nor does it have, it seems to me, much to do with the problems that the island has.  If you want to talk about the urgent, I also suggest that we urgently call for the closure of Guantanamo, which Mr Trump has said will remain open for twenty-five years: it does seem that this is a human rights issue, right? And also to restore that part of sovereignty to Cuba.  And finally, I believe that this urgency is no stranger to a fact that will occur in this same month, which is the trip of the President of the Government of Spain to the island. It's been thirty years since a president of the Spanish government has been traveling to the island. In this case, President Sanchez is going to do it just because we now have a stable framework of relations with Cuba.  Of course there's still a lot of trouble! But that's what the framework for human rights dialogue is for.  That is the work that has been done from the European Union through the management of Mrs Mogherini, Mr Lambrinidis and the effort we all have to make to finally have a structured dialogue with that part of the world.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Author. – Mr President, with this urgency we are witnessing a clumsy attempt to re-edit aznar's common position, using human rights again, as an instrument of interference and change of government just as the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement signed between the European Union and Cuba is beginning to walk. There are actors in this Parliament who embrace the Trump agenda and seek to derail the normalization of relations between the European Union and Cuba. But as hard as you try, you're out of reality. They speak a deciduous language fueled by alleged wage opposition from outside the island. Look, today the Cuban people, with extraordinary participation, are debating their new Constitution, which will be ratified in a referendum. Its content will not be decided by the European Parliament or the European Union. And less, the mercenaries paid for by Miami or another capital of Europe. It will be decided by Cubans in full exercise of their sovereignty and independence.  (He refused to have a question asked by Tomá-Zdechovsk-in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.)

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Author. – Mr President, two years ago this Parliament decided to put an end to a completely irrational situation, namely that Cuba was the only country in Latin America with which the European Union had no relationship, the result of an expired common position and which made no sense. I do not understand exactly what we are doing with this text, since I believe that this Parliament showed a willingness to move forward and to normalise relations with the island.  It gives me the feeling that we want to create problems for the European External Action Service in the implementation of this Agreement, when we question that Mrs Mogherini is not accountable for the outcome of the implementation of this Agreement here — when she came very recently — or when it is implicitly said that the European institutions in Cuba, in her work, do not respect the basic principles of the EU , questioning the work of one of the best diplomats the European Union has, such as Mr Alberto Navarro.  So, it seems frankly to me that this is a totally unwelcome resolution and that what we should want is for this Agreement to work everywhere, including the human rights dialogue. And so I don't think this text takes place.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: author. – Mr President, colleagues, this is not about Spanish politics, and this is not against the Political Dialogue Agreement, it is in support of the implementation. I know Alberto Navarro maybe longer than many of you Spaniards in this Hemicycle. He is an excellent diplomat, but the fact is that we are implementing the dialogue for already two years with basically no results, and this is something that we need to acknowledge. Read the draft constitution. There is nothing about free elections there. Read the draft resolution; in it there are provisions about basically any measures, any force can that can be taken. This is in fact in support of the Cuban dissidents who are continuously harassed. This is in support of those, even the Laureats of the Sakharov Prize, who are not invited to EU events. This is in support of the opposition that is to be recognised not just by the Cuban regime but also by us. We should not be calling dictators friends, but we should be inviting these people to a dialogue. We should recognise them. It is not just a message to the Cubans emphasising the need to implement, but also a message to ourselves. So yes, please, who votes against this resolution basically votes against the basic rights of these people.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, the Agreement between the European Union and Cuba has been in place for a year now. That's why it seems totally logical to take stock now. I also recall that this agreement was a very important turn in the European Union's foreign policy towards the island. Unfortunately, on fundamental rights and freedoms, this year's balance sheet is not positive. Harassment and intimidation of human rights defenders continue to be detained in Cuban prisons by people of the quality of Eduardo Cardet. Today's resolution details more cases of arbitrary detention and human rights violations. The proposals for official visits by this Parliament continue to be rejected by the Cuban authorities. Unfortunately, there are no prospects for political change in Cuba either. The current constitutional reform project enshrines the single party system and also seeks to make it irreversible. The hopes of reform that were at the base of This Parliament's support for the Agreement with Cuba have been dashed for now. The annual human rights dialogue has to produce tangible results. It is not an end in itself, as it is intended here to say. There are many links that unso together with the Europeans with the Cuban people. We want for this the same as for us: respect for freedoms, pluralism and the rule of law.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to present two major concerns of the churches in Cuba to the European Commission and also to the EU delegation in Havana.  First, because of the explosive growth in the number of Christians, the churches are in dire need of new houses of worship. However, the Cuban government does not allow this new building, even at registered churches. Commission, your embassy in Havana, I trust that you will defend this essential core issue of religious freedom – worship in legal houses of worship – against the Cuban authorities. Or do they sometimes strive for a proliferation of house churches? I can hardly imagine that. Secondly, Christian organisations in Europe have been ready for years to provide basic social care to all ailing Cuban citizens, but without the current harmful government control. For example, the Cuban government itself created an illegal aid circuit. Commission, EU delegation in Havana, agendeer and convince Cuban authorities that bilateral outside aid, from Europe, should reach 100% directly to the needy citizens. That's social, that's for Cuba!

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, fellows, we have concluded four European Union-Cuba dialogue agreements, and what are they for? After four years from the first, the situation remains dire, despite what the Sanchista left and its partners say.  Human rights defenders and political dissidents are arbitrarily detained and imprisoned. Let us not deceive ourselves: in Cuba there is no freedom of expression and assembly. Anyone who dares to think differently from the regime is persecuted and censored.  There is no political pluralism as in normal democracies, and the new draft Constitution does not seem to fix it. Conversely, it strengthens the power of the Communist Party and includes surreal provisions, such as banning future generations from deciding their own form of government.  As my colleague Mr Teliska says, this is not a discussion between Spaniards; it is about the rights of the Cuban people and the values of all Europeans.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, we reject the systematic disrespect and interference in sovereign countries promoted from Parliament. We denounce the spurious instrumentalisation of human rights in this strategy, an issue in which the European Union does not have the authority to preach. It is regrettable that this is what is intended to be made of the process of normalisation and development of relations between the European Union and its Member States with Cuba with the conclusion of the agreement for political dialogue and cooperation. We reaffirm Cuba's unquestionable example of internationalism, cooperation and solidarity response to serious humanitarian situations in third countries.  We welcome the advances of the Cuban revolution, a country without hunger, without illiteracy, with health and free education for all, advances achieved despite the criminal economic and financial blockade that the United States has imposed on Cuba for almost sixty years, a blockade whose purpose is required, as reiterated in the last United Nations General Assembly by all countries, with the exception of the United States and Israel.  It is up to the people of Cuba to sovereignly define their own path of development and the model of society they want to build.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The list of registered speakers has been completed. We proceed with the catch-the-eye process. We have a time pressure problem, because it is Thursday today and the votes must start at 12.00 p.m. I have received six requests, all from the same political group. Four of the six colleagues have already spoken this morning in the catch-the-eye process, so - due to the lack of time - I will only accept the two requests of colleagues who have not made use of the catch-the-eye procedure.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I believe that the European Union cannot let up in promoting human rights wherever this happens. I was intrigued by the words of my colleague Urtasuna, who asked why we wanted to enter into something that works. Human rights dialogue works, but if human rights dialogue works, that does not mean that human rights work in Cuba if there are a hundred and thirty political prisoners and others who are persecuted.  I believe that the European Union must have this dialogue, but it must also see what the results are. If the results are not, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to come forward so that it becomes clear that we will not let up. Political pluralism and free opposition is our objective on this issue. I hope the Socialists too.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, democracy is part of dialogue, and I think that dialogue is ed through the exchange of positions with each other. I think that the fact that this Parliament has blue cards in place shows that it is open to dialogue. Dialogue can now deepen democracy. That is why I am a little taken aback by the fact that a colleague from the Communist Party refused to have this dialogue with me. I may know, colleague, why you refused. Because I don't think you've ever been to Cuba. You've never met people in opposition there, and you've never seen opposition leaders arrested. I have seen him, I have seen people who have gathered to express their belief that human rights, democracy, freedom is something that cannot be exchanged for a pate, as you are exchanging it in a number of countries. It is one thing about democracy and freedom to speak, another is about democracy and freedom to live. In conclusion, let me express one thing – the blind man is not the one who does not see, but the one who does not want to see.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: My decision on catch-the-eye is final and I would ask you not to waste any more time on this matter. Mr Faria, you have the floor on the point of procedure. Please invoke the rule of procedure on the basis of which you are asking for a say in the procedure.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, catch the eye is a mechanism that is available to Members when they do not have the opportunity to express their voice in any other way. I did a catch the eye in this house today. And therefore I thank you for let me exercise my right to speak, to express my opinions here, please, and that you do not, as many have done here in this House, which is to cut the floor to freely elected Members. Please, i'm sorry.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr Faria, I do not want you to violate the Rules of Procedure. You don't have the floor. We have all been freely elected but, under the Rules of Procedure, the President-in-Office has the right to choose how to use the catch-the-eye procedure. I remind you that there are times when no one takes the floor based on catch-the-eye. I explained earlier that for four of the six requests, all six of which have been submitted by the same political group, the right of catch-the-eye was used this morning. I would therefore ask you to respect both the time and the fact that we have one more debate and the vote must begin at 12.00 p.m.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, we have to accept your decision. I understand that, but normally there are at least five taken. You have a request for six. It was four extra minutes. We lost several minutes all along, but we have to accept your decision. It was unnecessary though.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Thank you so much for respecting my decision. You know very well - because this is not the first time I have presided over - that whenever we have time I accept all requests, even if it is more than five. This time I ask you to respect my decision, because you all know very well that all the arguments have been heard from all sides with complete comfort. There's not a single argument that hasn't been heard. (End of catch-the-eye process)

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, almost two years ago, the European Union, our Member States and Cuba, signed a new agreement – the so—called Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement – which opened a new chapter in our relations with Cuba. Around a year ago this agreement entered into provisional application, after having received Parliament’s overwhelming support in its assent vote. While there is broad—ranging agreement on political dialogue and cooperation, it was very clear from the beginning that human rights should be a central part of it, and even before its formal application we started holding human rights discussions, both in Brussels and Havana. Last May, at the Joint Council meeting, Federica Mogherini and the Cuban Foreign Minister decided to start formal political dialogues on a number of areas. The very first formal political dialogue we had with Cuba was precisely the Human Rights one held last month in Havana. This was an important point for us to underline the continued relevance of human rights in our bilateral relations. For the first time, it involved the participation of our EU Member States as observers, and the organisation of a civil society seminar in its margins. We all know that there are still important differences between the EU and Cuba on many issues, notably on the way human rights and democracy are applied. This is why during last month’s Human Rights Dialogue we raised important matters, such as the need for ratification and implementation of the relevant international instruments on human rights, proper legal guarantees in criminal proceedings, freedom of association and expression, and the protection of human rights defenders.  The civil society seminar that was organised in the margins of the Dialogue tackled the situation of LGBTI groups and gender equality. While only registered Cuban civil society organisations were able to attend the seminar on this occasion, we recalled the importance to enlarge these discussions to the whole range of civil society, whether registered or not.  I would like to give some numbers about our projects. Most of these projects, indeed for around EUR 10 million, are implemented by European and Cuban civil society organisations, including religious organisations. Vulnerable Cuban people’s rights have been specifically addressed by a number of these projects – women, elderly people, people with disabilities and LGBTI – lesbian, gay, bisexual and so on. We will continue raising this, and all other subjects that are close to our hearts, with our Cuban counterparts in different meetings. Human rights need to be promoted on a day—to—day basis.  I would like to reiterate our conviction that the best way to address the differences we have with Cuba in these matters is through a process of dialogue based on clear and consistent messages. It is certainly difficult and trying, but it is the best manner to sustain results in the long term and to contribute to Cuba’s and its population’s path to reform and modernisation.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the end of the discussions.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the human rights situation in Bangladesh (2018/2927(RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, Bangladesh has, for many years, struggled with the problem of terrorist threats. Given the similar problems we see in our own countries, we are only too aware that preventing threats from turning into attacks is a difficult and costly business, so we do so with the benefit of more resources in the European Union, better intelligence and fewer potential threats. Despite the progress Bangladesh has made in recent years, it remains one of the poorest countries in the world, with a population of over 150 million people. As such, we must therefore remain cautious when criticising its efforts to tackle clear and present threats. Nevertheless, this cannot be routinely offered as a blanket universal explanation, and in cases such as the jailing of the photographer Shahidul Alam we cannot deny that the provisions of the Information and Communication Technology Act (ICT Act) are, at times, being used inappropriately by the government. I welcome therefore today’s resolution and, as a close friend of Bangladesh, call for the authorities there to avoid bringing its counterterrorism measures into disrepute. Finally, as we approach the elections next month, I call on all parties to participate peacefully and hope that we will not see a repeat of the violence that we saw five years ago.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Bangladesh had embarked on a virtuous and improving path, only that the approaching elections probably precipitated the situation again, therefore with a fight against all forms of dissent, a reduction in fundamental freedoms, a fight against freedom of information and therefore an unacceptable attitude on the part of the government on our part.  What is also surprising, which I think we need to talk about, is that Bangladesh has also become a member of the Human Rights Council. Given the presence of Saudi Arabia and the Philippines, we should ask ourselves whether this Human Rights Council is not the Council of Human Rights Violators, perhaps a reflection should be made. Let us remember that Bangladesh benefits from the preferential regime in the 'Everything but arms' programme, which provides for respect for fundamental rights, so let us use our pressure to enforce them.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, we in the EU must remind Bangladesh of its international human rights obligations. There is a visible increase in attacks on, and arrests of, journalists, students, human rights defenders and members of the political opposition. This crackdown on civil society must stop. Bangladesh must safeguard media freedom and freedom of expression and release all activists, journalists and students. The rates of early marriage are still alarmingly high in Bangladesh. It has one of the highest rates of child marriage in the world. Bangladesh has to ensure that the minimum age of marriage for women is 18, without exceptions. I also urge the Government of Bangladesh not to return thousands of Rohingyas living in the refugee camps in Cox’s Bazar to Myanmar against their will and in spite of objections by the UN.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Mr President, I speak as the Chair of Parliament’s Delegation for relations with the countries of South Asia, which covers Bangladesh. As we know, it’s a relatively young country still facing many difficulties and is looking forward to its full graduation from ‘least-developed country’ status. Part of that graduation is due to the ready—made garment sector, and government and manufacturers know that change is needed. So we’re concerned that the government has decided not to take full advantage of all that the accord offers in terms of assisting that change and building on progress to safe and inclusive working environments. We also recognise, as my colleague has said, the government’s zero—tolerance policy towards terrorism. But that approach has to be built on human rights, and we’re concerned about continuing unexplained disappearances, extrajudicial killings and the direction of legislation at the moment. Lastly, I too would echo the call for an open and inclusive, peaceful election – in which all parties participate – to give the people of Bangladesh a full and meaningful choice.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Mr President, disappearances, executions, torture, arbitrary detentions, trade union and press repression. This is happening today in Bangladesh, one of the European Union's main trading partners. A country that has agreed with Myanmar/Burma to start the forced return of the Rohingya and has sent the army to refugee camps to further intimidate that population. A country that does not want to renew the Agreement on Fire Prevention and Safety that it signed after the fire and the crime of Rana Plaza. How quickly we forget the tragedies! We reject the forced repatriation agreement and demand that Bangladesh accept the extension of the Agreement on Fire Prevention and Safety. Once again, we call on the Commission to launch an investigation into non-compliance with international conventions and to propose binding legislation on due diligence obligations for supply chains in the garment sector. We can't keep looking the other way. We have to have clear demands.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, Shahidul Alam is well-known photographer and a human rights defender, and under the controversial Digital Securities Act and ICT Act for online speech, he is now accused of ‘speech that hurts the image of the nation in Bangladesh’, while we consider it to fall under his right to freedom of expression. We call for his release and for the dropping of all charges against him. Sadly, Alam is not the only one repressed in Bangladesh. There is a pattern of harassment, arrests and enforced disappearances, and we call on the High Representative to assess whether Bangladesh still complies with the trade arrangements we have under the ‘anything but arms’ agreement, because conditionality and accountability are very important when it comes to human rights and we must do what we can to improve the situation.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union has long been one of the largest and most stable partners and supporters of a young state such as Bangladesh. I think that it is precisely this openness of dialogue that should be much greater, especially in the area of human rights. The European Union must not close its eyes to what is happening in Bangladesh. That is because, within the Group on Good Governance and Human Rights, we have a mandate to oversee what is happening in the country. Even so, state power is being abused in this country. The government is letting the journalists and activists who oppose it disappear. I think that this is absolutely unacceptable and it is necessary to speak out against it repeatedly. Journalists, activists, lawyers, human rights defenders, all of them are currently victims of the regime. The resolution concerns two specific cases of a journalist and a lawyer who have fought for human rights. Both of these people have disappeared from the world and no one knows where these activists are at the moment. There is a reasonable suspicion that the government is tossing or disposing of these persons out of court. We must urgently call on the government to comment on these cases and have an active dialogue on compliance with international obligations. In particular, the rights to a fair trial, the rights of the defence, the right of access to the court, which must be respected. Human rights activists and campaigners are a very important part of any democracy and it is essential that they have a place in this system.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There is no doubt that enforced disappearances, that is, ordinary kidnappings carried out by the apparatus of power, are one of the strategies of soothing terror and forcing submission in societies. By creating a sense of uncertainty and intimidation, the authorities can more easily control societies and enforce submission. Unfortunately, despite Bangladesh's declaration to strengthen its cooperation with the European Union in the protection of human rights, this practice continues to apply in the country, as confirmed, for example, by the disappearance of Shahidul Alam.  The use of enforced disappearances does not justify any exceptional circumstances, but in the Alam case, the reason why it occurred is even more appalling. It is worth recalling that this human rights defender criticised the government and stood up for those who demand greater road safety. We do not have our consent to such actions and there should be no agreement of the European Union to intimidate and torture political opponents.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the collapse of the Rana Plaza factory was a wake—up call for the whole world to improve the working conditions in the ready—made garments industry. Unfortunately, at the end of the month, due to a highly questionable verdict, the Bangladesh Accord will be thrown out of the country. This means that the safety of thousands of workers in the garment industry in Bangladesh is at stake. As we all know, the Government of Bangladesh is not yet capable of taking over the inspections of the garment factories, and, as we all know, the labour law reform in the country is still pending. As we also all know, freedom of association is not guaranteed in Bangladesh. Therefore, let us be clear to the Bangladeshi authorities that they need to get serious about workers’ rights and safety. If you want to use the EU trade preferences, you have to fulfil the commitments we agreed upon.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I speak as Chair of the South Asia Trade Monitoring Committee. We have constantly been appealing to the Government of Bangladesh to make progress on its commitments under the Everything but Arms scheme, to democracy, human rights and the rule of law. Whilst we can see that there has been an improvement, more needs to be done. The accord is at a critical juncture, and commitments from the Government of Bangladesh towards the Sustainability Compact are highly insufficient, as demonstrated by the technical status report recently published. The roadmap is here, requirements are on the table, and now we need to see tangible results and steps in the right direction. It must be clear that we are at a crucial stage, and we are moving ever so slowly from issuing further notifications for action to actual action. It has been initiated in terms of investigative reviews for withdrawal of Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP) mechanism for Myanmar and Cambodia. Bangladesh could be next on the list.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, freedom of expression in Bangladesh is under attack. This is no surprise, as this year Bangladesh is ranked 146 out of 180 on the World Press Freedom Index. We see visible signs that the authorities have increased their crackdown on civil society and government critics, with such means as detentions, enforced disappearances and the use of violence. In addition, on 5 August, writer, former journalist and activist  Shahidul Alam was imprisoned after speaking out against state violence on the student protest in Dhaka. This must stop. I call the government to repeal its Digital Security Act used to crack down on dissidents and human rights defenders and immediately release Shahidul Alam. I call on the Commission to assess if the tariff preferences that Dhaka enjoys for the time being under the Everything but Arms agreement should not be put under question. The EU cannot be just a watcher in this regard.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, we will be sending a warning message to Bangladesh on the eve of the December elections. The lights are red. Violence, arrests, arbitrary detentions and extrajudicial executions are on the rise. The war on terror and the war on drugs have a good back. The photographer Shahidul Alam, the blogger Limon Fakir or, worse, Shahzahan Bachchu, murdered last June, are unfortunately just a few examples. Socially, it is not much better. After the horror of The Rana Plaza, little has changed despite the commitments. Textile workers remain among the lowest paid in the world, security conditions remain catastrophic and a new tragedy is possible at any time. Fast Fashion continues to be the law and European multinationals are still the main beneficiaries. Finally, in short, I associate our voice with those who are asking Bangladeshis not to implement the Agreement on the Rohingya. That would send them to death, so it is not possible.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, general elections will be held in Bangladesh on 30 December. As these deadlines approach, the true nature of who in power could lose their role in the event of defeat emerges.  Bangladesh is a country which, despite a whole series of problems, received the compliments of the UN last May, which, in the Universal Periodic Review, assessed The Dacca's progress as remarkable. The situation changed very and very quickly. We are witnessing a violent repression of the freedom of expression of the media and opposition, as well as arrests, enforced disappearances and the use of torture. Photojournalist Shahidul Alam is a case in point. Ladies and gentlemen, the EU has with Bangladesh the 'Everything but arms', a tariff exemption that we grant to developing countries on all goods, excluding weapons. Well, this mechanism of suspension clauses linked to respect for human rights, but if we do not have the courage to mention those clauses, to activate them when appropriate, we will always look like a giant with feet of clay, a large business market as usual and nothing more. Is this the image we want to give of Europe in the world?

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: – Mr President, the situation in Bangladesh is very worrying. The country is facing growing repression against civil society, political activists and human rights defenders. There are reports of extrajudicial executions, mass arbitrary arrests and enforced disappearances. Press freedom is under attack and bloggers are increasingly intimidated. General elections are due by the end of this year, but freedom of expression, which is a prerequisite for fair elections, does not exist. The Opposition is fundamentally constrained and its leader, Khaleda Zia, has been barred from contesting these elections and sentenced on politically motivated charges.  The forthcoming elections set the country at a crossroads. This is a last chance: either return to democracy and the rule of law, or slip into lawlessness and chaos. Europe will be faced with the consequences if this happens. I appeal to the authorities to establish conditions where people can freely speak out and can prepare for fair elections.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The list of registered speakers has been completed. We proceed with the catch-the-eye process. I've received seven requests. Normally, provided that the votes start at 12.00 p.m., I would have to accept only two of them, those who have not spoken under the catch-the-eye procedure. However, I am informed by my colleagues from the services that the Conference of Presidents has not yet been completed. Having said that, I am proceeding with the procedure for one of each political group, so that no colleagues are wronged.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On this occasion, I would like to draw attention to one very important element: the inflation of similar resolutions. Please note that on Bangladesh we had resolutions of November 2015, April 2017, June 2017, a statement of September 2018 and a report also from that year. For obvious reasons, I will vote in favour of this resolution, but I would point out that the number of these resolutions does not translate into the actual ability of the European Parliament or our institutions to exert certain pressure on the Bangladeshi authorities to make the reality in this country change in accordance with the values that are closest to us.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, the first time I heard about Bangladesh, I was a child. George Harrison's legendary Bangladesh concert broke news to those of us who knew nothing of a country where there was bloodshed, wars, natural disasters and flooding. And more than forty years later, the situation is not much better.  We hear of Bangladesh in relation to enforced disappearances, torture, police abuse, discrimination against the LGTBI collective, exploitation of child labour and child marriages; and for the tragedy of Rana Plaza in 2013, which prompted a cross-cutting security agreement in buildings, which must be fulfilled in all its terms. Shahidul Alam is under arrest for defending him.  And it is imperative that the European Union, which is Bangladesh's first trading partner, use all diplomatic force not only to achieve liberation, but to restore the agreement in all its terms, and for the European Union to ensure that its diplomacy and development cooperation are influential for the protection of the fundamental rights of the most vulnerable , in a country that continues to give bad news for its catastrophes and its disasters.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Bangladesh is the paradise of multinationals: over-exploitation of workers, over-exploitation, hunger wages, no regulation and no protection of workers. We had the case of Rana Plaza, with 1127 dead and 2500 injured – all employees – because the health and safety standards of workers are not respected. And, of course, we are now going into an authoritarian regime. There is no freedom of expression, activists are persecuted, they do not have a fair trial, and the death penalty has now begun to be imposed, which must be abolished. At the same time, an attack on the Rohingya themselves has now been launched. There needs to be labour rights, the right of association and, of course, an end to the European Union's preferential trade treatment with Bangladesh, so that we can enforce compliance by the authorities.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, I think it is important that we meet here every week in Strasbourg on Thursday and discuss the human rights situation in other countries. I believe that it is necessary to ask the Government of Bangladesh why it is not improving the conditions of workers in its own country, it is necessary to know why the government has been intimidating and arresting trade union leaders in the long term and has not made fundamental reforms that would allow Bangladeshi workers to fight for their rights. At the same time, however, it is necessary to look at our home, our clothing stores. If we do, we have to ask why so many European companies are still not being told that their suppliers in Bangladesh are ignoring the most basic social, environmental and human rights. The answer is clear: Why not get your pocket on cheap work? The old rule of capitalism is that "buy cheaply and sell dearly" and there is no place for human rights and human dignity in this equation.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the arrest, detention and alleged torture of the award—winning photographer Shahidul Alam shines a light on the poor human rights situation in Bangladesh. Alam is the founder of many important cultural, media and training initiatives in South Asia. He’s also a visiting professor at Sunderland University in the UK. His arrest, 100 days ago, for criticising the government’s response to the Bangladesh road-safety protests, points to the worrying global trend of many governments to silence artists and journalists. So I call for the immediate and unconditional release of Shahidul Alam and for all charges against him to be dropped. I also call for the Bangladeshi authorities to provide him with the urgent medical assistance he needs. These attacks on freedom of expression and assembly in Bangladesh, as well as women’s, girls and LGBTIQ+ rights give wider cause for concern. The High Representative should take all necessary diplomatic steps to put pressure on the Bangladeshi government to improve its human rights record, starting with the release of Shahidul Alam.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, Bangladesh is approaching general elections under the worst circumstances. The government has embarked on a campaign of intrusive surveillance upon its own citizens. It is monitoring social media and curtailing freedom of expression in the name of national security. The Digital Security Act has gagged the media and all those who criticise the government and the harassment and intimidation of journalists and activists grows on a daily basis. Peaceful political dissent should not be silenced or criminalised. We urge the government to revise the Digital Security Act, halt the crackdown on freedom of expression and conduct investigations into the cases of enforced disappearances. We want Bangladesh to progress towards a functioning democracy, not drift into an authoritarian police state.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union has a substantial and long-lasting relationship with Bangladesh. Our political dialogue has intensified over the past months in the context of the refugee crisis.  We appreciate the Government’s and people of Bangladesh’s efforts to host the Rohingya refugees. The return of the refugees to their place of origin remains the objective, but it must be voluntary, safe, sustainable and dignified. It should not go against those fundamental requirements. It is important that the return of refugees is conducted in line with international law and with the involvement of UNHCR. It is critical that the conditions in Rakhine State are conducive for a safe and sustainable return.  Human rights are a key priority of our dialogue with Bangladesh. The EU regularly expresses its concerns on the situation of human rights, and we see it as a positive development that the Government of Bangladesh is engaging with the EU on this issue.  In joint press statements adopted at the Sub-group on Good Governance and Human Rights in April, and at the Diplomatic Consultations held in Dhaka in July, the authorities undertook to address the shortages and enforce policies respectful of human rights, fundamental freedoms and democracy. However, the situation is of serious concern and more needs to be done: human rights and fundamental freedoms are being increasingly challenged as parliamentary elections are coming close. While continuing its dialogue with the Government of Bangladesh, together with EU Member States and other like-minded partners on the ground, the EU has addressed this in a number of recent public statements. This was particularly necessary in the context of the reaction to the recent Digital Security Act and violence against students and press during the summer. We are notably very concerned over the situation of Mr Shahidul Alam.  The preparation of the parliamentary elections is discussed regularly with the Bangladeshi authorities. The EU expects that the upcoming elections will be held in a transparent, inclusive and impartial way. The rule of law, freedom of expression and freedom of peaceful assembly should be upheld and protected. The Government needs to ensure a safe and enabling environment for civil society, journalists and human rights defenders. As regards labour rights, the Government needs to fully implement the International Labour Organization’s recommendations, notably on freedom of association.  Human rights are a crucial part of the EU’s development cooperation with Bangladesh, with more than EUR 40 million committed for democratic governance. The EU focuses on ensuring democratic ownership through engagement with civil society, promoting democratic empowerment and local governance, notably by addressing access to justice.  (Applause)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the end of the discussions.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, why does a text which was adopted in the committee speciality by 30 votes in favour and only 7 against, with a mandate of 32 votes in favour and 15 against — less than half - become the subject of all battles to revoke the mandate against all parliamentary logic and tradition? There is one explanation: obviously, it is not to improve the text, which will be done and to a large extent in the tripartite negotiations, which are plentiful and already planned. What happens is that there are powerful, powerful, totally legitimate lobbies, of course who very much prefer that there be no directive on this issue in this legislature. They know that one way to achieve a 'non-directive' is to delay the processes, since, with a small delay, it becomes practically impossible to finish our work in this mandate. Here's what's at stake, having or not having a directive. Different visions of Europe are at stake behind them, obviously. The one who believes in a citizens' Europe cannot allow us to present ourselves empty-handed before an election campaign in front of the citizens who demand protection and attention from us. We did not consider taking to the streets to say that Europe has not been able to take the citizen into account in the face of accelerated changes in the market and technologies.
